including but not limited to recreational areas, and other property, or
portions thereof, owned or operated by the City of Harrah, including but not
limited to vehicles and equipment owned by the Municipality.
OUTDOOR AREA: Means any area that is not an indoor area, and includes outdoor
recreational area.
SMOKING: Means carrying by a person of a lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe, or
other lighted smoking device.
TOBACCO PRODUCT: Means any product that contains tobacco and is intended for
human consumption. Tobacco product does not include any product approved by the
United States Food and Drug Administration for sale as a tobacco cessation
product.
VAPOR PRODUCTS: Means any noncombustible product, that may or may not contain
nicotine, that employs a mechanical heating element, battery, electronic
circuit, or other mechanism, regardless of shape or size, that can be used to
produce a vapor in a solution or other form. Vapor product shall include any
vapor cartridge or other container with or without nicotine or other form that
is intended to be used with an electronic cigarette, electronic cigar,
electronic cigarillo, electronic pipe, or similar product or device and any
vapor cartridge or other container of a solution, that may or may not contain
nicotine, that is intended to be used with or in an electronic cigarette,
electronic cigar, electronic cigarillo, or electronic device. (Ord. 2019-4, 3-
14-2019)
8-902: PROHIBITED CONDUCT:
   A.   Smoking tobacco products is prohibited in all places in which smoking
tobacco products is prohibited by Oklahoma State law.
   B.   Using tobacco products and vapor products is prohibited on all
Municipal property, indoor and outdoor, including parks and recreational areas.
   C.   Nothing in this chapter prohibits any person or entity from prohibiting
the use of tobacco products or vapor products on their property, even if the
use of tobacco products or vapor products is prohibited by law.
   D.   No person or entity shall knowingly permit the use of tobacco products
or vapor products in an area that is under the control of that person or entity
and in which the use of tobacco products or vapor products is prohibited by
law.
   E.   No person or entity shall permit the placement of ash receptacles, such
as ash trays or ash cans, within an area under control of that person or entity
and in which smoking is prohibited by law. However, the presence of ash
receptacles shall not be a defense to a charge of use of tobacco products or
vapor products in violation of any provision of this chapter.
   F.   No person shall dispose of tobacco product or vapor product waste
within an area in which the use of tobacco products or vapor products is
prohibited.
   G.   No person or entity shall intimidate, threaten, or otherwise retaliate
against another person or entity that seeks to attain compliance with this
chapter. (Ord. 2019-4, 3-14-2019)
8-903: REQUIRED SIGNS:
   A.   The person or entity that has legal or de facto control of an area in
which the use of tobacco products or vapor products is prohibited by this
chapter shall post a clear, conspicuous, and unambiguous sign at each point of
entry to the area, and in at least one other conspicuous point within the area.
   B.   For restrictions on the use of tobacco products and vapor products in
indoor areas, the sign or decal shall be at least 4 inches by 2 inches in size
and shall clearly state that smoking or tobacco use is prohibited or that a
tobacco-free environment is provided. For restrictions on the use of tobacco
products or vapor products in the outdoor areas, signs shall be weather-
resistant, at least 15 inches by 15 inches in size, with lettering of at least
one inch (1"), and shall clearly state that smoking or tobacco use is
prohibited or that a tobacco-free environment is provided.
   C.   For purposes of this section, the City Manager or his/her designee
shall be responsible for the posting of signs on Municipal property, both
indoor and outdoor.
   D.   Notwithstanding this provision, the presence or absence of signs shall
not be a defense to a charge of the use of tobacco products or vapor products
in violation of any other provision of this chapter. (Ord. 2019-4, 3-14-2019)
8-904: PENALTIES AND ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Enforcement of this chapter shall be the responsibility of the City of
Harrah Police Department. In addition, any peace officer or Code enforcement
official may enforce this chapter.
   B.   Any person who knowingly violates this chapter shall be punished by a
citation and fine not less than ten dollars ($10.00) and not more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) in accordance with this chapter.
   C.   The possession of a lighted tobacco product in violation of this
chapter is a nuisance.
   D.   The remedies provided by this chapter are cumulative and in addition to
any other remedies available at law or in equity.
   E.   Each instance of tobacco product or vapor product use in violation of
this chapter shall constitute a separate violation.
   F.   The use of a vapor product in violation of this chapter is a nuisance.
   G.   Causing, permitting, aiding, abetting, or concealing a violation of any
provision of this chapter regarding tobacco product or vapor product use shall
also constitute a violation of this chapter.
   H.   In addition to other remedies provided by this chapter or by other law,
any violation of this chapter regarding tobacco product or vapor product use
may be remedied by the City Attorney, including, but not limited to,
administrative or judicial nuisance abatement proceedings, Criminal Code
enforcement proceedings, and suits for injunctive relief. (Ord. 2019-4, 3-14-
2019)
PART 9
LICENSING AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS, CANVASSERS
SECTION:
9-101: Definitions
9-102: Permit Or License Required
9-103: Persons Excluded From Chapter
9-104: Application For Permit Or License
9-105: Investigation Of Applicant And Issuance Of License Or Permit
9-106: Transfer Of License Prohibited
9-107: Exhibition Of License
9-108: Permit And License Fees
9-109: Minimum Age Of Applicant
9-110: Bond
9-111: Food Trucks, License Required
9-101: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply in this chapter:
BUSINESS: An occupation, profession, trade or service, or the purchase and sale
of goods in an effort to make a profit.
PEDDLER: Means and includes the words "hawker" and "huckster" and means any
person who travels by foot or by any type of conveyance from place to place,
from house to house, or from street to street carrying, conveying or
transporting goods, wares or merchandise of whatsoever nature, offering and
exposing the same for sale, or who, without traveling from place to place,
shall sell or offer the same for sale from any vehicle or conveyance or on any
public street or thoroughfare.
SOLICITOR AND CANVASSER: A person who travels by foot or by any type of
conveyance from place to place, from house to house or from street to street,
taking or attempting to take orders for the sale of goods, wares, merchandise
or personal property of whatsoever nature for future delivery or for services
to be furnished or performed in the future. (Prior code § 5-1; amd. Ord. 2003-
7, 9-18-2003)
9-102: PERMIT OR LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person or persons shall engage in business, except as expressly excluded by
this code, without first obtaining a permit or license therefor and paying the
prescribed fee or fees as established in section
9-108 of this chapter. (Ord. 2003-7, 9-18-2003)
9-103: PERSONS EXCLUDED FROM CHAPTER:
   A.   The following persons are hereby specifically excluded from the
application of the provisions of this chapter:
      1.   Persons engaged in selling personal property at wholesale to dealers
in such property.
      2.   Merchants having regular places of business in the city, and their
employees, in taking orders at the houses of their customers for goods held in
stock at the places of business, and in delivering the goods so ordered.
      3.   Newsboys selling newspapers.
      4.   Milk deliverymen operating in compliance with the provisions of this
code relating to milk and food handling.
      5.   Schools or other nonprofit organizations. (Prior code § 5-3)
      6.   Rental of single-family residences.
      7.   Permit or license requirements specifically provided in other
chapters of this code, in order to prevent a requirement of duplicate permit or
license.
      8.   Persons under eighteen (18), or student, who does lawn care for a
fee. (Ord. 2003-7, 9-18-2003)
9-104: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT OR LICENSE:
   A.   Applicants for a permit or license hereunder shall file with the city
clerk in duplicate a sworn application in writing on a form to be furnished by
the city clerk.
   B.   The application shall give the following information:
      1.   Name and brief description of applicant.
      2.   Address, both legal and local.
      3.   Nature of business and kinds of goods to be sold, and if applicant
is a farmer or truck gardener, whether the goods are produced by him on lands
he owns, cultivates and controls.
      4.   If employed by another, the name and address of applicant's employer
together with a brief description of credentials showing the exact
relationship.
      5.   Length of time for which the right to do business is desired.
      6.   Description and license number or other identification of any
vehicle to be used. (Prior code § 5-4)
9-105: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT AND ISSUANCE OF LICENSE OR PERMIT:
   A.   Upon receipt of an application for permit or license, the city clerk
shall refer one copy to the chief of police who shall note thereon any record
concerning applicant which may appear from the official records in his charge
and return the same promptly to the city clerk.
   B.   The city clerk shall cause such other investigation or inquiry to be
made concerning application as he may deem necessary to determine the character
and business responsibility of applicant and whether his application is in
compliance with the terms and conditions of this chapter.
   C.   If, as a result of the investigation, the character and business
responsibility of applicant are found to be satisfactory and application is in
compliance with the terms and conditions of this chapter, the city clerk, upon
payment of the prescribed permit or license fee, shall issue the permit or
license. (Prior code § 5-5)
9-106: TRANSFER OF LICENSE PROHIBITED:
No license issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be used at any
time by any person other than the one to whom it was issued. (Prior code § 5-6)
9-107: EXHIBITION OF LICENSE:
Peddlers, solicitors and canvassers are required to exhibit their licenses at
the request of any citizen. (Prior code § 5-7)
9-108: PERMIT AND LICENSE FEES:
There is hereby levied a schedule of fees for the permits and licenses required
which shall be adopted by resolution from time to time by the Harrah city
council and maintained on a schedule of fees. (Prior code § 5-8; amd. Ord.
2003-7, 9-18-2003)
9-109: MINIMUM AGE OF APPLICANT:
   A.   No license shall be issued under this chapter to any person under the
age of sixteen (16) years.
   B.   No licensee under this chapter shall employ, apprentice, engage, or
suffer, cause or allow any minor under the age of sixteen (16) years to be
employed, apprenticed or engaged, either as a huckster, peddler, hawker, helper
or solicitor in connection with the business licensed under this chapter.
(Prior code § 5-9)
9-110: BOND:
Peddlers, hucksters, hawkers, solicitors and canvassers shall provide a cash or
surety bond in the sum of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) in addition to
the license fee, as provided herein. (Prior code § 5-10)
9-111: FOOD TRUCKS, LICENSE REQUIRED:
   A.   License Required To Operate A Food Truck: It shall be unlawful and an
offense for any person, firm or organization to operate a food truck without a
license to do so issued by the city.
      1.   Application For License: Each applicant for a license to operate a
food truck shall file with the city clerk a sworn application in writing on a
form to be furnished by the clerk, which shall include the following
information and such other information as the clerk shall deem pertinent:
         a.   Name and brief description of applicant;
         b.   Address, both personal and business;
         c.   Nature of business, kinds of foodstuffs to be sold;
         d.   Whether low point beer or alcoholic beverages are to be sold;
         e.   If employed by another, the name and address of applicant's
employer together with credentials showing the exact relationship;
         f.   Description and license number or other identification of any
vehicle to be used;
         g.   Food manager's certification from a source approved by the city-
county health department;
         h.   A criminal history by name search from the Oklahoma state bureau
of investigation; and
         i.   The name of any employee who will be operating the food truck or
serving therefrom.
This information must be kept current throughout the duration of the license.
if any of the information included on the application for the license changes,
including the applicant or any of his employees being convicted of a crime, the
applicant must provide that information to the city clerk. Failure to do so
shall be a violation of this section and shall constitute grounds for
revocation of the license.
      2.   Health Regulations: All food truck operators shall comply with all
state and city-county health regulations and other recognized health practices.
The application of any person desiring a license to operate a food truck must
include a copy of the applicant's food manager's certificate obtained in
compliance with the city-county health laws. The city reserves the right to
revoke any license issued under this section for noncompliance with such health
regulations immediately and without notice.
      3.   License Fee: A fee established by council for an annual license to
operate in the city limits shall be paid at the time the license is issued and
shall not be prorated. Food truck licenses shall be effective for the period
September 1 through August 31 each year.
   B.   Signs: Any signage pertaining to or advertising a food truck and/or its
menu shall be limited to and attached to the food truck.
   C.   Violations: Every date a food truck is operated in violation of this
section shall constitute a separate offense. Penalties shall be as provided in
this code.
   D.   License Revocation: Any license issued under this section may be
revoked or any application for issuance of a license may be refused if the
application submitted by the applicant contains any false, fraudulent or
misleading statement. The city reserves the right to immediately and without
notice revoke any license for noncompliance.
   E.   Other Permits: Should this code or any applicable statute or regulation
require any other permit(s) in order to operate a food truck, such additional
permits must be obtained prior to a food truck operating. (Ord. 2016-2, 4-28-
2016)
CHAPTER 2
PRIVATE SECURITY OFFICERS OR ORGANIZATIONS; LICENSING AND REGULATING
SECTION:
9-201: Purpose Of This Chapter
9-202: Definitions
9-203: Rules And Regulations To Implement Chapter
9-204: General Standards Of Conduct
9-205: False Advertising
9-206: Badge And Uniform
9-207: Restrictions On Areas Or Locations Served, Changes With Regard To Such
Areas Or Locations
9-208: Color, Identification, Equipment And Inspection Of Vehicles
9-209: Security Officers Not City Police Officers, Authority To Carry Weapons
And Make Arrests
9-210: Report Of Discharge Of Firearms
9-211: Report Of Arrests
9-212: Reports Of Suspected Law Violations
9-213: Responding To Police Calls
9-214: City Not Liable For Officer's Actions Or For Damages Suffered By Officer
9-215: License Required
9-216: Filing And Contents Of Application
9-217: Applicant To Furnish Report Of Physical Examination
9-218: Minimum Age Of Applicant
9-219: Investigation And Photographing Of Applicant
9-220: Applicant's Bond Or Insurance
9-221: Fee
9-222: Chief Of Police To Act On Application Within Fifteen Days, Temporary
License Pending Action
9-223: Issuance Or Refusal
9-224: To Be Carried On Person
9-225: Expiration And Renewal
9-226: Suspension Or Revocation
9-227: Exemptions And Restrictions
9-201: PURPOSE OF THIS CHAPTER:
The purpose of this chapter is to provide procedures for licensing and
regulating private security officers or organizations offering their services
as independent contractors within the city. (Prior code § 5-11)
9-202: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation of this chapter,
unless a different meaning is clearly indicated to the contrary:
BUSINESS DAY: Monday through Friday, both inclusive, but excluding holidays.
GUARD SERVICE: Stationary armed guards serving private citizens at a particular
and specified place or location.
PATROL SERVICE: A motorized armed patrol serving private citizens or companies
in a specified geographical area, which area shall be established by naming the
streets forming the exterior boundaries of the area serviced.
PERMANENT SECURITY SERVICE: Regularly armed scheduled service furnished hourly,
daily, weekly, monthly or for any other period at a specified area, place or
location.
PRIVATE SECURITY COMPANY: An organization or security system offering services
as an independent contractor and employing armed private security officers. A
one man operation shall not be considered a private security company.
PRIVATE SECURITY OFFICER: Any person providing patrol or guard service as an
independent contractor and authorized to carry firearms under the provisions of
this chapter.
TEMPORARY SECURITY SERVICE: Service not offered on a regularly scheduled basis.
(Prior code § 5-12)
9-203: RULES AND REGULATIONS TO IMPLEMENT CHAPTER:
The chief of police shall promulgate and publish, with the approval of the city
board of trustees such additional rules and regulations as are consistent with
this chapter and as may be necessary to its implementation. Copies of same
shall be furnished applicants and licensees under this chapter upon request.
(Prior Code, Sec. 5-13)
9-204: GENERAL STANDARDS OF CONDUCT:
Private security officers shall at all times conduct themselves in a manner
befitting their authority, and with that dignity required of a private security
officer. (Prior Code, Sec. 5-14)
9-205: FALSE ADVERTISING:
The use of false, fraudulent or misleading advertising or representation by any
private security officer or company is specifically prohibited. (Prior Code,
Sec. 5-15)
9-206: BADGE AND UNIFORM:
A private security officer, when on duty, shall wear a uniform, badge or other
emblem of authority approved by the chief of police, which shall, in any event,
be clearly distinctive and different from that of regular city police officers
and shall designate the officer as a "private officer", "security officer" or
"security service". (Prior Code, Sec. 5-16)
9-207: RESTRICTIONS ON AREAS OR LOCATIONS SERVED, CHANGES WITH REGARD TO SUCH
AREAS OR LOCATIONS:
   A.   Private security officers and companies shall at all times service only
the place or specifically defined geographical area where they are authorized
to serve under the provisions of this chapter.
   B.   The chief of police, with the approval of the police commissioner shall
designate the specific place or area and hours of the day that each private
security officer or company may furnish permanent security patrol service.
   C.   Before a private security officer or company performing patrol service
may service additional areas, application must be made and approved and a fee
of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be charged for processing.
   D.   Before a private security officer or company performing guard service
may furnish permanent security service at an additional place or location,
notification must be made to the chief of police.
   E.   Before a private security officer or company shall furnish temporary
security service at an additional place or location, the chief of police shall
be notified of the name of the company or officer, the place or location, and
the anticipated duration of service.
   F.   When permanent service is discontinued in an area or at a location,
written notification shall be sent to the chief of police. (Prior Code, Sec. 5-
17)
9-208: COLOR, IDENTIFICATION, EQUIPMENT AND INSPECTION OF VEHICLES:
   A.   Vehicles used by private security officers providing patrol service
shall be a solid color. They shall have on each door, in four inch (4") block
letters, the words "Private Security Patrol" or the name of the private
security company. The lettering shall be permanently attached to the vehicle.
Auxiliary lights on the vehicle shall be white or blue. The use of black and
white cars, red lights and sirens is prohibited.
   B.   Each vehicle used on duty by a private security officer may be equipped
with radio equipment capable of transmitting and receiving on the city police
frequency. Such equipment shall be used only in accordance with FCC
requirements and regulations of the police department. The vehicle may be
equipped with a two-way radio which allows communication with a company
supervisor or dispatcher who has available communications with the police
communications bureau.
   C.   Each vehicle used by private security officers shall be subject to
inspection by the police department. (Prior Code, Sec. 5-18)
9-209: SECURITY OFFICERS NOT CITY POLICE OFFICERS, AUTHORITY TO CARRY WEAPONS
AND MAKE ARRESTS:
Private security officers are not members of the city police department and
shall not have the authority of a city police officer. Such an officer shall,
while on duty at his assigned place, have the right to carry a pistol or
revolver and make arrests only as a private citizen is granted such authority
by state statutes. (Prior code § 5-19)
9-210: REPORT OF DISCHARGE OF FIREARMS:
   A.   If at any time a private security officer fires a weapon within the
city, other than on a properly constituted and approved firing range, an
immediate report shall be made to the police department, and a written report
must be submitted to the chief of police within twenty four (24) hours, setting
out all particulars of the incident. (Prior code § 5-20; amd. Ord. 2014-05, 6-
19-2014)
9-211: REPORT OF ARRESTS:
Any time an arrest is made by a private security officer, the officer shall
notify the police department immediately for orders as to disposition of the
prisoner. (Prior code § 5-21)
9-212: REPORTS OF SUSPECTED LAW VIOLATIONS:
When a private security officer observes or is aware of an incident or
suspected incident involving the peace and safety of the citizens of the city
or the violation of any ordinance or law, he shall immediately report the same
to the police department. (Prior code § 5-22)
9-213: RESPONDING TO POLICE CALLS:
Private security officers shall not respond to police calls. (Prior code § 5-
23)
9-214: CITY NOT LIABLE FOR OFFICER'S ACTIONS OR FOR DAMAGES SUFFERED BY
OFFICER:
Any private security officer, while in the performance of his duties as a
private officer, shall not be an agent, servant or employee of the city, and
the city shall not be liable for his actions to third parties; nor shall the
city be liable to the private officer for any compensation for his services;
nor shall the city be liable for any injury or damage he might suffer. (Prior
code § 5-24)
9-215: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It is unlawful for any person to act as a private security officer or operate a
private security company within the city, unless he has a current license so to
do issued pursuant to this chapter. It is unlawful for any such company to
employ any private security officer unless such officer is so licensed. (Prior
code § 5-25)
9-216: FILING AND CONTENTS OF APPLICATION:
   A.   Each applicant for a license under this chapter shall make written
application on forms available at the police department. Such application shall
contain the following information:
      1.   Private security officer for guard service:
         a.   Company, if any, employing the applicant;
         b.   A standard personal history statement completed on a form
provided by the chief of police; or
         c.   Other and additional information deemed necessary by the chief of
police;
      2.   Private security company for guard service:
         a.   Names of the officers, principals or resident managers of the
company;
         b.   A standard personal history statement for such persons, completed
on a form provided by the chief of police; or
         c.   Other and additional information deemed necessary by the chief of
police;
      3.   Private security officer for patrol service:
         a.   The specific place or area where services would be rendered;
         b.   Hours of the day when services would be rendered if the applicant
is self-employed;
         c.   The company, if any, employing the applicant;
         d.   A standard personal history statement completed on a form
provided by the chief of police; or
         e.   Other and additional information deemed necessary by the chief of
police;
      4.   Private security company for patrol service:
         a.   The names of the officers, principals or resident manager of the
company;
         b.   A standard personal history statement for such persons completed
on a form provided by the chief of police;
         c.   The specific area or properties where the service would be
furnished, and the hours of the day that service would be furnished;
         d.   The names of the officers who are to service the area; or
         e.   Other and additional information deemed necessary by the chief of
police. (Prior Code, Sec. 5-26)
9-217: APPLICANT TO FURNISH REPORT OF PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:
Within five (5) days from the date of filing an application for a license under
this chapter, the applicant shall submit a report of a physical examination
(not over 1 year old) from a duly licensed physician. (Prior Code, Sec. 5-27)
9-218: MINIMUM AGE OF APPLICANT:
Each applicant for a private security officer's license shall be at least
twenty one (21) years of age. (Prior Code, Sec. 5-28)
9-219: INVESTIGATION AND PHOTOGRAPHING OF APPLICANT:
Prior to issuance of a license under this chapter, the police department shall
conduct a complete background inquiry of the applicant. The applicant shall be
personally interviewed by the chief of police and the applicant's photograph
and fingerprints shall be obtained. Each such applicant shall be interviewed as
to his ability to safely handle firearms. After having been so interviewed, he
shall satisfactorily demonstrate his ability to properly and safely handle
firearms. (Prior Code, Sec. 5-29)
9-220: APPLICANT'S BOND OR INSURANCE:
Prior to issuance of a license under this chapter, each individual applicant
shall file with the city clerk a surety bond or certificate of insurance of
general liability in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), made by a
duly qualified bonding or insurance company licensed to do business in the
state. Each company filing an application for a license under this chapter may
file a one hundred thousand dollar ($100,000.00) bond or certificate of
insurance which will eliminate the necessity of its employees filing individual
bonds or certificates. The appropriate bond or certificate of insurance shall
be renewed and filed annually with the application for renewal. A copy of a
general liability bond or certificate of insurance on file with the state will
satisfy the requirements of this section. (Prior Code, Sec. 5-30)
9-221: FEE:
The annual fee for a license under this chapter shall be ten dollars ($10.00)
for an individual private security officer and one hundred dollars ($100.00)
for a private security company. (Prior Code, Sec. 5-31)
9-222: CHIEF OF POLICE TO ACT ON APPLICATION WITHIN FIFTEEN DAYS, TEMPORARY
LICENSE PENDING ACTION:
The chief of police shall act on an application for the issuance or renewal of
a license under this chapter within fifteen (15) business days from the time of
submission of the application. Pending action by the chief of police, a
temporary license may be issued in a case where the delay in granting would
cause undue hardship on the applicant. (Prior Code, Sec. 5-32)
9-223: ISSUANCE OR REFUSAL:
   A.   Subject to all provisions of this chapter, the chief of police is
hereby authorized to issue a license to a private security officer or company,
when the applicant meets the requirements of this chapter.
   B.   It is the duty of the chief of police to refuse to issue a license
under this chapter to all persons having been convicted of a felony under the
laws of the state or of any other state or of the United States, or any offense
involving moral turpitude, and to all minors, drug addicts, unnaturalized
foreign-born persons, and such persons as he has reasonable cause to believe
are not of sound mind.
   C.   If the chief of police refuses to issue a license under this chapter,
an appeal may be made to the city board of trustees. (Prior Code, Sec. 5-33)
9-224: TO BE CARRIED ON PERSON:
A private security officer licensed under this chapter shall carry his license
on his person at all times when he is on duty. (Prior Code, Sec. 5-34)
9-225: EXPIRATION AND RENEWAL:
A license issued under this chapter shall expire on January 31 next following
its issuance. An application for renewal need not be reprocessed, but shall be
filed with the police department by January 31. Unless the application is
received by January 15, the license shall be terminated, without further action
on January 31. (Prior Code, Sec. 5-35)
9-226: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION:
The license of any private security officer or private security company may be
suspended or revoked at any time by the chief of police for violation of any of
the requirements set out in this chapter or for violation of any rule or
regulation established pursuant to this chapter. Upon a violation occurring,
the chief of police shall give the private security officer or private security
company notice of any suspension or revocation hearing at least five (5) days
prior to the date of public hearing. Such notice shall be furnished by mail.
The suspension or revocation hearing well be conducted by the city board of
trustees. (Prior Code, Sec. 5-36)
9-227: EXEMPTIONS AND RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   This chapter shall not apply to duly appointed and acting police
officers of the city serving as private security officers on their off duty
hours when the service involves working for any branch or agency of the state,
federal or municipal governments, or when specifically authorized in writing by
the city administrator.
   B.   No police officer of the city may work more than a total of twenty (20)
hours per week as a private security officer. (Prior Code, Sec. 5-37)
CHAPTER 3
PERMITS FOR DANCES, GARAGE SALES, AMUSEMENTS
SECTION:
9-301: Permits Required For Conducting Private Sales, Dances, Circuses, Or
Carnivals
9-301: PERMITS REQUIRED FOR CONDUCTING PRIVATE SALES, DANCES, CIRCUSES, OR
CARNIVALS:
   A.   A permit, setting forth the specific date for which it shall be valid,
shall be obtained from the city clerk to conduct a dance, rummage sale, garage
sale, yard sale, circus or carnival and any person, firm, or corporation so
applying shall pay a fee as follows:
 
1. Circus or carnival for a period of 7 consecutive days               $  10.00
2. Rummage, garage or yard sale pursuant to provisions of this section 10.00
3. Dances for each specific date                                       100.00
 
   B.   It is further provided that any nonprofit charitable organization may
obtain a permit as set out without the payment of the fee set out in subsection
A of this section.
   C.   "Residential sale" shall mean any sale held out to be or commonly known
as garage, room, porch, yard or any other type of general sale conducted from
or on any premises not located in zoning district which permits such sales.
   D.   It is unlawful for any person to hold, conduct, engage in or allow a
residential sale to be held or conducted on premises under his control or
ownership more often than every three (3) months, and in no event shall the
total number of such sales exceed four (4) in any twelve (12) month period.
   E.   A fee shall be paid to the city for each residential sale held in
accordance with these regulations.
   F.   A permit will be issued to any person for a residential sale not to
exceed four (4) consecutive days in compliance with this section provided the
applicant is in compliance with the requirements of this chapter and other
ordinances of the city.
   G.   Regulations governing signs or other advertising devices are as
follows:
      1.   The maximum length of time for any residential sale shall not exceed
four (4) consecutive days.
      2.   No sign shall be posted more than two (2) days prior to the sale.
      3.   Signs are to be removed by the permittee within forty eight (48)
hours of the end of the residential sale.
      4.   Signs are not to be placed on utility poles, trees, culverts or
bridges or any other structure being part of streets or roadway.
      5.   Signs must be dated with the dates of the sale and permit number.
   H.   If for any reason the applicant is unable to hold sale as scheduled,
the permit may be voided or changed if returned to the city hall by twelve
o'clock (12:00) noon on the first day of the scheduled sale. If the sale is to
begin on a Saturday or Sunday, the permit must be returned by five o'clock (5:
00) P.M. the preceding Friday.
   I.   If the applicant is unable to return the permit as provided herein, the
three (3) month interval between sales will apply. (Prior code § 5-38; amd.
Ord. 1992-8, 4-16-1992; Ord. 1992-16, 8-20-1992; per correspondence dated 9-7-
2010)
CHAPTER 4
FIREWORKS
SECTION:
9-401: Sale Of Fireworks Unlawful
9-402: Exceptions
9-403: Applications And Permits
9-401: SALE OF FIREWORKS UNLAWFUL 1
, 2
:
   A.   For the purpose of this section, "fireworks" shall be as defined in
section 1622 of title 68 of the Oklahoma Statutes.
   B.   Except as otherwise specifically provided in this chapter, it is
unlawful for any person to sell, store, or have in his possession for the
purpose of sale any fireworks of any size, type, or description. (Prior Code,
Sec. 8-9)
 
Notes
1 1. 68 OS § 1621 et seq.; 11 OS § 22-110.
2 2. See also section
  10-303 of this code.
9-402: EXCEPTIONS:
   A.   The city manager may issue a temporary permit authorizing the sale of
fireworks and related items from nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. June 15 through July
5 of any year, and upon such conditions and restrictions as may be deemed
advisable or necessary by the city manager. (Ord. 1997-14, 9-4-1997)
   B.   The city manager may issue a temporary permit authorizing the sale of
fireworks and related items from nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. December 26, 1999,
through five o'clock (5:00) P.M., January 1, 2000, if the permit complies with
such conditions and restrictions as may be deemed advisable or necessary by the
city manager.
   The applications and permits shall comply with section
9-403 of this chapter, except that the dates are as follows:
      1.   The application shall be received by the city clerk not later than
November 30, 1999.
      2.   Removal of the stand and cleanup shall be completed by January 9,
2000, or the deposit shall be forfeited.
      3.   The use, firing, igniting, lighting or discharge of fireworks within
the city is unlawful except on December 31, 1999, and January 1, 2000, except
as otherwise authorized and except those displays authorized by the city
council under control of qualified persons. It is unlawful to discharge, use,
fire, ignite or light any bottle rocket or stick rocket in the city at any time
or to discharge any fireworks from, across or onto any road, street or highway.
(Ord. 1999-10, 8-19-1999)
9-403: APPLICATIONS AND PERMITS:
   A.   Written application and site plan shall be filed with the city clerk
not later than May 31 of each year. (If property is not owned by applicant,
written authorization from property owner shall be submitted with application.)
   B.   The fee for a permit under this section shall be two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00) and shall be paid to the city clerk prior to the issuance of
the permit. However, no fee shall be charged to schools or other nonprofit
organizations which operate primarily within the city limits.
   C.   If the location of any stand to be set up for the sale of fireworks
does not constitute a hazard to the health, safety, and welfare of the
community, the city manager may authorize the city clerk to issue the permit
for the period of time specified in this chapter, with such restrictions as may
be deemed advisable and necessary.
   D.   A permit shall not be issued under this section until the applicant
files satisfactory evidence with the city clerk showing minimum liability
coverage of one hundred thousand dollars/three hundred thousand dollars/one
hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00/$300,000.00/$100,000.00) limits which
protect the city, and deposit the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) in
addition to the fee prescribed in subsection B of this section, to guarantee
full compliance with all restrictions set by the city manager and the
ordinances of the city, and the removal of the stand used by applicant not
later than the following July 11.
   E.   Failure to comply with any restriction imposed by the city manager,
ordinances of the city, state law or the removal of the stand by July 11, shall
immediately invalidate the permit and cause the forfeiture of the one hundred
dollar ($100.00) deposit.
   F.   Any person aggrieved by the forfeiture may appeal within ten (10) days
from the date of notice by the city of the forfeiture to the council by filing
written notice of appeal with the city clerk.
   G.   A permit issued under this section shall authorize the use of one stand
for the sale of fireworks, one storage facility for the storage of fireworks to
be sold on premises, one security unit and two (2) ground signs, none of which
shall encroach upon any street right of way. Permit holder must also provide
adequate sanitary bathroom facilities and comply with all city of Harrah
building codes. All structures and signs shall be included in the site plan.
Any variances in the site plan must be approved in writing by the city manager.
   H.   The permit will authorize a total sales area of not more than eight
feet by thirty two feet (8' x 32'). (Ord. 1997-14, 9-4-1997)
CHAPTER 5
PAWNBROKERS
SECTION:
9-501: License
9-502: Pawnbroker's Bond
9-503: Records, Tickets Required
9-504: Thumbprints Required For Pawnbrokers, Gold And Metal Transactions
9-505: Inspection Of Records Or Merchandise
9-506: Business Hours
9-507: Stolen Property Prohibited
9-508: Concealing Lost Property
9-509: Certain Sales Prohibited
9-510: Prohibition On Purchases Or Loans To Minors
9-511: Soliciting Business On Streets
9-512: Suspicious Circumstances To Prevent Sale
9-513: Penalty
9-501: LICENSE:
   A.   No person shall operate as a pawnbroker or as a receiver of goods under
chattel mortgage without first securing a city license and making payment
therefor as herein provided.
   B.   There is levied a license fee in the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) per
year for the operation of the business of pawnbroker. All licenses shall expire
on April 30 after they are issued; provided any license issued hereunder after
November 1 of the calendar year shall be charged a one-half (1/2) year license
fee.
   C.   Any pawnbroker who is guilty of a violation of any provision of this
chapter, or who shall permit any employee in the course of such employment to
be guilty of a violation of any provision hereof, in addition to the fine
otherwise provided as a penalty therefor, shall be deprived of his license upon
conviction; and upon such conviction the municipal judge shall order such
license revoked. (Ord. 1986-3, 3-6-1986)
9-502: PAWNBROKER'S BOND:
   A.   Every person hereafter applying for a license to engage in or carry on
the business of pawnbroker, shall before such license is issued to him, enter
into a bond with the city with approved sureties, in the penal sum of one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00), conditioned that:
      1.   The applicant will strictly and faithfully observe all ordinances,
regulations, and requirements of the city in relation to pawnbrokers or their
business.
      2.   The applicant will pay all costs, fines and penalties incurred on
account of his failure or neglect in that behalf.
      3.   The applicant will pay all damages resulting to any person by reason
of his wrongfully taking, purchasing, or receiving in pledge or on deposit any
stolen property, or the property of any minor.
The bond shall be filed with the city clerk and may be sued upon by any person
for damages, in the name of the city for the use of such person, but in no
event shall the city be liable for the cost of such suit or be liable as a
party to the suit. (Ord. 1986-3, 3-6-1986)
9-503: RECORDS, TICKETS REQUIRED:
Every pawnbroker shall keep at his place of business a register in which he
shall enter in writing a minute description of all property taken, purchased,
or received by him, including any number that may be in or upon any article,
which registry shall be kept clean and legible. The register shall also include
the time, name, and place of residence (giving street and number) of the person
leaving the property, and including the amount loaned, the interest charged,
and the time when the loan falls due. He shall make such entry within one hour
after the receipt or purchase of such property. Every entry shall be made in
ink and shall not in any manner be obliterated or erased. The person
negotiating or leaving such property, shall be given a plainly written or
printed ticket, having upon it a full and perfect copy of all the entries
required to be kept in such register, for which copy no charge shall be made.
It is the duty of every pawnbroker to make out and deliver to the chief of
police, or any police officer upon demand, a legible and correct copy from the
register of all personal property or other valuable things received, deposited,
or purchased, the time when received or purchased, and a description of the
person who left the property or from whom same was purchased. No person shall
be required to furnish such description of any property purchased from
manufacturers or wholesale dealers having an established place of business, of
any goods purchased at open sale or from any bankrupt stock, or from any other
person having an established place of business. However, such goods must be
accompanied by a bill of sale or other evidence of open and legitimate
purchase, and must be shown to any officer when demanded. (Ord. 1986-3, 3-6-
1986)
9-504: THUMBPRINTS REQUIRED FOR PAWNBROKERS, GOLD AND METAL TRANSACTIONS:
   A.   It is unlawful for any pawnbroker to fail to obtain a legible
thumbprint of every person selling or pawning any personal property received by
pawnbroker. The thumbprint shall be obtained by utilizing a system commonly
known as "Ident-a-Print" or other similar systems as recognized by the chief of
police. Each thumbprint shall be attached to a written or printed ticket of all
personal property received, deposited, or purchased, and a description of the
person by whom left in pledge or from whom the same was purchased. The
description shall consist of identification, height, weight, sex, race, hair,
eyes, age, address, and date of birth. The thumbprint shall be delivered to the
chief of police or his designee upon demand.
   B.   It is unlawful for any person engaged as a dealer or broker in the sale
of gold or other precious metal to fail to obtain a legible thumbprint of every
person selling any gold or other precious metal to the dealer or broker. A
thumbprint shall be obtained by utilizing a system commonly known as "Ident-a-
Print" or other similar system as recognized by the chief of police and each
thumbprint shall be attached to a written or printed ticket of all personal
property purchased, and a description of the person from whom the same was
purchased. The description shall consist of identification, height, weight,
sex, race, hair, eyes, age, address, and date of birth. The thumbprint shall be
delivered to the chief of police or his designee upon demand.
   C.   The requirements of subsection B of this section are not required for
transactions involving sales between precious metals and gem dealers licensed
under the provisions of sections 1521 through 1532 of title 59 of the Oklahoma
Statutes, except that the dealer license number, address, telephone number and
signature of the seller shall be obtained and delivered to the chief of police
or his designee upon request. (Ord. 1986-3, 3-6-1986)
9-505: INSPECTION OF RECORDS OR MERCHANDISE:
The register required by this chapter shall at all times be kept open to the
inspection of the chief of police and the sheriff of the county, the deputy of
either, any officer of the police force of the city, the city attorney, the
district attorney of the county, and anyone authorized in writing for that
purpose by the chief, major, or captain of the police force, which authority
shall be exhibited to the pawnbroker. The pawnbroker shall, upon request, show
and exhibit to such person or officer for inspection, any articles purchased,
taken, or received by him. (Ord. 1986-3, 3-6-1986)
9-506: BUSINESS HOURS:
No pawnbroker shall purchase, take, or receive on deposit, or in any other
manner, from any person, any article of property between the hours of six
thirty o'clock (6:30) P.M. and eight thirty o'clock (8:30) A.M. All pawnbrokers
shall remain closed all day on Sunday and legal holidays; provided that
pawnbrokers may receive and purchase property up to nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. on
Saturdays and Mondays, when such days are not legal holidays. (Ord. 1986-3, 3-
6-1986)
9-507: STOLEN PROPERTY PROHIBITED:
   A.   It is unlawful and an offense for any pawnbroker to purchase, take, or
receive, keep in possession of, or dispose of, any stolen property or to
conceal such property, to fail to promptly inform some proper office of the
possession thereof.
   B.   Any person who steals the property of another in any other city, state,
county or country, and brings the same into this city may be convicted and
punished in the same manner as if such larceny had been committed in this city;
and for such purpose, such larceny may be charged to have been committed in
this city. (Ord. 1986-3, 3-6-1986)
   C.   A list of all pawned or purchased items shall be provided to the city
police department within forty eight (48) hours. Upon written request, a copy
of the pawn tickets shall be provided. (Ord. 1993-14, 9-2-1993)
9-508: CONCEALING LOST PROPERTY:
Any person who shall attempt to conceal any stray or lost goods, found or taken
up by him, or shall efface any marks or brands thereon, or carry the same
beyond the limits of the city, or knowingly permit the same to be done, or
shall wilfully fail to cause the same to be advertised, sold, or otherwise
dealt with as provided by the chapter on lost goods, shall be deemed guilty of
an offense. (Ord. 1986-3, 3-6-1986)
9-509: CERTAIN SALES PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful, and an offense, for any pawnbroker, secondhand dealer, or any
other person to purchase, take or receive in pledge, by gift or on deposit, or
to accept possession of any article of property of or from any common drunkard
or from any person under the influence of intoxicating liquors or drugs, or
from any person who is a habitual user of drugs of any kind or from any person
who is commonly known to be a "police character", or from any person who has
previously been convicted of petit larceny. (Ord. 1986-3, 3-6-1986)
9-510: PROHIBITION ON PURCHASES OR LOANS TO MINORS:
It is unlawful and an offense for any person in charge of any junk shop,
secondhand store, pawnshop or otherwise, to purchase from or advance money to
any minor upon any thing or articles of value, or have any dealings respecting
the title of property in the possession of a minor, without the written consent
of the parent or guardian of such minor. (Ord. 1986-3, 3-6-1986)
9-511: SOLICITING BUSINESS ON STREETS:
It is unlawful, and an offense, for any person to solicit business for any
pawnshop from any person while such person is on the streets, alleys, sidewalks
or other public places within the city, or call to, or in any manner attract
the attention of, any person while such person is on the streets, sidewalks,
alleys, or any public place for the purpose of asking such person to patronize
any pawnshop. (Ord. 1986-3, 3-6-1986)
9-512: SUSPICIOUS CIRCUMSTANCES TO PREVENT SALE:
Any suspicion or circumstances sufficient to put an ordinary prudent person
upon their guard is sufficient notice to any person to whom property is offered
to gift, sale or pledge, to prohibit them from accepting same. Any knowledge,
notice, or information as to the improper character of the person offering same
must prevent such sale, gift, or pledge from being made until investigation
shall reveal that the same may be lawfully made. The failure to exercise the
precautions herein prescribed, and the accepting of a gift, sale, or pledge of
property prohibited herein, which is stolen or is in the possession of one not
entitled thereto, or which shall be disposed of by one not entitled to or
competent to sell, pledge or give the same away, is unlawful and shall
constitute an offense. (Ord. 1986-3, 3-6-1986)
9-513: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation or other legal entity which shall violate any
of the provisions of this chapter or fail to comply therewith or with any of
the requirements thereof is deemed guilty of an offense punishable as provided
in section
1-108 of this code. (Ord. 1986-3, 3-6-1986)
CHAPTER 6
PENALTY
SECTION:
9-601: Penalty
9-601: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation or other legal entity which shall violate any
of the provisions of this part or fails to comply therewith, or with any of the
requirements thereof, shall be deemed guilty of an offense punishable as
provided in section
1-108 of this code. (Prior Code, Sec. 5-39)
CHAPTER 7
VENDING MACHINES
SECTION:
9-701: Definitions
9-702: License Required
9-703: Fees
9-704: Decals Required
9-705: Term Of License
9-706: Failure To Obtain License
9-707: State License Required
9-701: DEFINITIONS:
   A.   As used in this chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
    COIN-OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICE: Any and all nongambling mechanical or
electronic machines which, upon the payment or insertion of a coin, token, or
similar object, provide music, amusement or entertainment, including, but not
limited to, such games as:
      1.   Pool;
      2.   Phonographs;
      3.   Video television;
      4.   Shooting galleries;
      5.   Pinball;
      6.   Foosball;
      7.   Bowling;
      8.   Shuffleboard; or
any other amusement device with or without a replay feature which can be
legally shipped interstate according to federal law.
   COIN-OPERATED BULK VENDING DEVICE: A machine or device which, upon the
payment or insertion of a coin, token or similar object dispenses to the
purchaser:
      1.   Ballpoint pens;
      2.   Combs;
      3.   Cigarette lighters;
      4.   Prophylactics;
      5.   Filled capsules;
      6.   Peanuts;
      7.   Gumballs;
      8.   Mints;
      9.   Perfume; or
      10.   Novelties.
   COIN-OPERATED DEVICES: Means:
      1.   Coin-operated music devices.
      2.   Coin-operated vending devices.
      3.   Coin-operated bulk vending devices.
   COIN-OPERATED MUSIC DEVICE: Any such music device which is operated,
motivated, released, or played by or upon the payment or insertion of a coin,
token or similar object, whether there is one or more boxes or devices in the
premises for the reception of such coins, tokens or similar objects; coin-
operated radio or television receiving sets in hotels, motels or tourist cabins
for the use and benefit of the guests and visitors of such hotels, motels, or
tourist rooms or cabins shall be included in such definition.
   COIN-OPERATED VENDING DEVICE: Any and all machines or devices which, upon
the payment or insertion of a coin, token or similar object, dispense tangible
personal property, including, but not limited to:
      1.   Cigarettes;
      2.   Candies;
      3.   Gum;
      4.   Cold drinks;
      5.   Hot drinks;
      6.   Sandwiches; or
      7.   Chips.
It shall not mean vending machines or devices used exclusively for the purpose
of selling services, such as:
      1.   Pay telephone booths;
      2.   Parking meters;
      3.   Gas and electric meters; or
      4.   Other distribution of needful service.
   MUSIC DEVICE: Any and all mechanical devices which render, cause to sound,
or release music where the same may be heard by one or more public patrons, and
each separate loudspeaker, phonograph, jukebox, or outlet from which such music
emits shall each be construed to be a separate "music device" as herein
defined; except in the case where the music emits from more than one speaker
transmitting from the same music-producing mechanism in which case the several
outlets or speakers in each place of business shall be collectively considered
one such music device. (Ord. 1989-8, 8-3-1989)
   B.   Every person who owns and has available to any of the public for
operation, or who permits to be operated in or on his place of business, any
coin-operated devices shall pay for such privilege an annual fee to be set
forth in the fee schedule adopted from time to time by the city council. Until
amended by such fee schedule, the original fee for each coin-operated music
device or coin-operated amusement device and for each coin- operated vending
device requiring a coin or thing of value of twenty five cents ($0.25) or more
shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00). (Ord. 1989-8, 8-3-1989; amd. Ord. 1991-
15, 8-15-1991)
9-702: LICENSE REQUIRED:
Any person owning a coin-operated device or operating the premises where the
same is to be operated or exposed to the public, shall apply to the city for a
license for such device and shall, at the same time, pay to the city the annual
fee herein levied. (Ord. 1989-8, 8-3-1989)
9-703: FEES:
   A.   Every person who owns and has available to any of the public for
operation, or who permits to be operated in or on his place of business, any
coin-operated devices shall pay for such privilege an annual fee as follows:
      1.   For each coin-operated music device or coin-operated amusement
device, thirty seven dollars fifty cents ($37.50). (Ord. 1989-8, 8-3-1989)
      2.   For each coin-operated vending device requiring a coin or thing of
value of twenty five cents ($0.25) or more, twenty five dollars ($25.00).
      3.   Notwithstanding subsections A1 and A2 of this section, the fee for
vending or coin-operated devices shall not, in any event, exceed seventy five
percent (75%) of the fee imposed by the state where such a fee is imposed by
state law. (Ord. 1989-8, 8-3-1989; amd. Ord. 1996-9, 6-6-1996)
9-704: DECALS REQUIRED:
Any person owning a coin-operated device or operating the premises where the
same is to be operated or exposed to the public, shall apply to the city for a
decal for such device and shall, at the same time, pay to the city, the annual
fee herein levied. The city shall, upon receipt pay of such payment and
approval of such application, issue a license for the type of coin-operated
device covered by such application and payment. Any number of coin-operated
devices may be included in one application. Before any coin-operated device is
put in operation or placed where the same may be operated by any of the public,
and at all times when the same is being operated or available to any of the
public for operation, a license shall be firmly affixed to the coin-operated
device covered thereby, and plainly visible to and readable by the public.
(Ord. 1989-8, 8-3-1989)
9-705: TERM OF LICENSE:
For the purpose of the license issued under this chapter, the fee year shall
begin on July 1 and end on June 30 and shall be divided into two (2) halves.
The city shall, in each instance, issue licenses for the remainder of the fee
year upon payment of the fee on the basis of the current and remaining half of
such fee year. (Ord. 1989-8, 8-3-1989)
9-706: FAILURE TO OBTAIN LICENSE:
Any owner of coin-operated devices who places such devices in operation or in a
place available to the public for operation, and any person who permits coin-
operated devices to be in operation or accessible to the public without a
license affixed as required by this chapter, shall be liable for the fee on
such device at the full annual rate as herein levied and shall be liable to a
penalty, in addition to the amount of the fee, in such sum as set in section
1-108 of this code. The penalty shall not be assessed until sixty (60) days
after July 31, 1989. (Ord. 1989-8, 8-3-1989)
9-707: STATE LICENSE REQUIRED:
To obtain a license for coin-operated devices, the applicant must possess a
valid state of Oklahoma permit for such device or otherwise present proof that
an application has been filed and approved. (Ord. 1989-8, 8-3-1989)
CHAPTER 8
RESIDENTIAL SALES
SECTION:
9-801: Residential Sale Defined
9-802: Number Of Sales Allowed
9-803: Signs Or Other Advertising Devices
9-804: License Required
9-805: Application Procedure
9-806: Fees
9-807: Collection Of Taxes
9-808: Penalty
9-801: RESIDENTIAL SALE DEFINED:
For the purpose of this chapter, the term "garage sale" means any sale held out
to be a garage, room, back yard, or patio sale, or any other type of general
sale conducted from or on any premises not located in a zoning district which
permits such sales, or goods or articles of any type held out for sale to the
public. This definition shall not include a situation where specific items are
held out for sale and all advertisements of such sales specifically names the
items to be sold. In any event, all sales or offers for sale, from any
residence, of more than three (3) articles or items shall require a license
under the terms of this chapter. (Ord. 2009-8, 9-10-2009)
9-802: NUMBER OF SALES ALLOWED:
It is unlawful for any person or organization to conduct more than four (4)
sales during any calendar year, provided that no license shall be issued for
any location at which four (4) sales have been held during the fiscal year.
(Ord. 2009-8, 9-10-2009)
9-803: SIGNS OR OTHER ADVERTISING DEVICES:
   A.   Not more than five (5) city issued signs used for the purpose of
advertising or otherwise calling attention to residential sales shall be
allowed for each residential sale permitted under this chapter.
   B.   Signs shall be self-supporting devices, placed inside the curb on the
public easement of main and side streets, with the owner's consent.
   C.   Signs or other devices are not to be placed on utility poles, trees,
culverts or bridges, or any other structure being part of the streets or the
roadway.
   D.   No sign is to be posted more than three (3) days prior to the sale.
   E.   Signs are to be removed by the person with the license number listed on
the signs within forty eight (48) hours of the sale.
   F.   Signs not removed within forty eight (48) hours of the last day of the
sale will constitute a violation of this chapter, an offense which will be
punishable by a fine as provided in section
9-806, "Fees", of this chapter.
   G.   All signs must clearly state up to three (3) dates of the sale and the
license number. (Ord. 2009-8, 9-10-2009)
9-804: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It is unlawful for any person to hold, conduct, engage in, or participate in
any manner in a residential sale, without having first obtained a license to do
so under this chapter. A separate license shall be required for each location
at which a residential sale is to be held. (Ord. 2009-8, 9-10-2009)
9-805: APPLICATION PROCEDURE:
Application for a license under this chapter shall be made on the form provided
by the city, copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk, shall
include the following information:
   A.   The full name and address of the applicant;
   B.   The location at which the proposed residential sale is to be held;
   C.   The day or dates upon which the sale shall be held; and
   D.   The serial or identification number of each article to be sold, on
those items from which serial numbers can be obtained. (Ord. 2009-8, 9-10-2009)
9-806: FEES:
The license fee under this chapter shall be as set by the city for each
separate license granted to any party under this chapter. (Ord. 2009-8, 9-10-
2009)
9-807: COLLECTION OF TAXES:
The license holder for any residential sale shall be held responsible for
collecting taxes from the proceeds of any such sale in accordance with state
law, and submitting the appropriate sales tax report. (Ord. 2009-8, 9-10-2009)
9-808: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation or other legal entity which shall violate any
of the provisions of this chapter or fail to comply herewith, or with any of
the requirements hereof, shall be deemed guilty of an offense punishable by a
fine as provided in the schedule of fines adopted by the city council and
maintained by the city clerk. (Ord. 2009-8, 9-10-2009)
PART 10
OFFENSES AND CRIMES
CHAPTER 1
OFFENSES IN GENERAL
SECTION:
10-101: Attempts To Commit An Offense
10-102: Aiding In An Offense
10-103: Offense Defined
10-104: Violation Defined
10-105: Penalty Not To Excuse Offense
10-106: Capacity To Commit Offense
10-107: Intoxication, No Defense
10-108: Witness, Self-Incrimination
10-109: Nuisances
10-110: Conspiracy
10-111: Crimes And Punishments
10-101: ATTEMPTS TO COMMIT AN OFFENSE:
Every person who attempts to commit an offense against the ordinances of the
city, and in such attempt does any act toward the commission of such offense,
but fails or is prevented or intercepted in the perpetration thereof, is guilty
of an offense, and shall be punished in the manner prescribed for the attempted
offense itself. (Prior code ch. 14, as amended)
10-102: AIDING IN AN OFFENSE:
When no punishment for counseling or aiding in the commission of a particular
offense is expressly prescribed by ordinance, every person who counsels or aids
another in the commission of such is guilty of an offense, or misdemeanor, and
punishable in the same manner as the principal offender. (Prior code ch. 14, as
amended)
10-103: OFFENSE DEFINED:
The word "offense", whenever used in this code or in any title, chapter or
ordinance of the city means the unlawful act of doing, or failing to do, some
particular act or thing construed therein to be detrimental to the general
welfare, morals, peace, health or safety of the inhabitants of the city. (Prior
code ch. 14, as amended)
10-104: VIOLATION DEFINED:
The word "violation" means the doing of any of the acts or things prohibited,
or failing to do any of the acts or things commanded to be done, as more fully
specified and set forth by any provision of this code or any part, or chapter
hereof, or future ordinances of the city, is hereby declared to be an offense
against the good order, public peace, morals, health, proper government and
welfare of the city and unlawful. (Prior code ch. 14, as amended)
10-105: PENALTY NOT TO EXCUSE OFFENSE:
The imposition of one penalty for any offense shall not excuse it or permit it
to continue, nor prevent the imposition of further penalties, should the
offenses be continued or permitted to continue. (Prior code ch. 14, as amended)
10-106: CAPACITY TO COMMIT OFFENSE:
   A.   All persons are capable of committing an offense as herein provided,
except those belonging to the classes following:
      1.   Children under the age of seven (7) years.
      2.   Children over the age of seven (7) years, but under the age of
fourteen (14) years, in the absence of proof that at the time of committing the
act or neglect charged against them, they knew its wrongfulness.
      3.   Lunatics, insane persons, and all persons of unsound mind, including
persons temporarily or partially deprived of reason, upon proof that at the
time of committing the act charged against them they were involuntarily
incapable of knowing its wrongfulness.
      4.   Persons who committed the act, or made the omission charged, under
an ignorance or mistake of fact which disproves any criminal intent. But
ignorance of the law does not excuse from punishment for its violation.
      5.   Persons who committed the act charged without being conscious
thereof, involuntarily.
      6.   Persons who committed the act, or made the omission charged, while
under involuntary subjection to the power of superiors. (Prior code ch. 14, as
amended)
10-107: INTOXICATION, NO DEFENSE:
No act committed by any person while in a state of intoxication, whether from
liquor or drugs, shall be deemed less an offense by reason of his being in such
condition. (Prior code ch. 14, as amended)
10-108: WITNESS, SELF-INCRIMINATION:
No person otherwise competent as a witness, shall be incapacitated, excused or
disqualified from testifying concerning the offense mentioned in any section,
chapter or part of this code, or any ordinances hereafter enacted on the
grounds that his testimony might incriminate him, but the testimony which may
be given by such witness shall in no case be used against him. (Prior code ch.
14, as amended)
10-109: NUISANCES:
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to permit, maintain, aid, abet, or
sanction a nuisance on or about any premises or premises owned by him or under
his control at any place within the corporate limits of the city. (Prior code
ch. 14, as amended)
10-110: CONSPIRACY:
Any two (2) or more persons assembled or who shall assemble with the intent to
mutually agree to do any unlawful act with force or violence and shall make any
movement therefor against the property of the city or the person or property of
another person shall be guilty of an offense. (Prior code ch. 14, as amended)
10-111: CRIMES AND PUNISHMENTS:
It is unlawful for any person to violate any of the misdemeanor provisions of
title 21, Oklahoma Statutes, crimes and punishment, which provisions are
adopted herein by reference as if fully set forth herein. (Ord. 2012-04, 9-20-
2012)
CHAPTER 2
OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY
SECTION:
10-201: Petit Larceny Prohibited
10-202: Injuring Automobiles And Other Vehicles
10-203: Destroying Or Injuring Buildings And Other Property
10-204: Placing Signs On Property Of Another
10-205: Tampering With Or Damaging Public Utilities, Larceny
10-206: Unlawful Intrusion Upon Land
10-207: Illegal Entrance
10-208: Throwing Advertising On Street Prohibited
10-209: Throwing Injurious Substances
10-210: Injury To Public Plants And Trees
10-211: Public Streets And Trees
10-212: Damaging, Destroying Trees, Plants Or Fruit, Trespass
10-213: Altering, Obstructing Gutters, Drains, Streams And Other Water Passages
10-214: Trespass Prohibited
10-215: Parking On Property Of Another Person Or Business
10-216: Improper Use Of Driveways And Parking Areas
10-217: Interference With Fire Hydrants
10-218: Defacing Public Property
10-219: Public Grounds, Use Of
10-201: PETIT LARCENY PROHIBITED 1
:
   A.   Petit larceny is the taking of personal property of value not exceeding
fifty dollars ($50.00) accomplished by fraud or stealth and with intent to
deprive another thereof, but it does not include the taking of such property
from the "person" of another.
   B.   Petit larceny is unlawful, and any person who commits larceny shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor. (Prior Code, Chapter 14, as amended)
 
Notes
1 1. 21 OS §§ 1704, 1706.
10-202: INJURING AUTOMOBILES AND OTHER VEHICLES 1
:
A. It is unlawful for any person to start, otherwise meddle with, molest,
enter, occupy, take or drive away any automobile or other vehicle belonging to
another, without the consent of the owner or person in charge thereof.
B. It is unlawful for any person to mutilate, deface or injure any automobile
or other vehicle, or to remove therefrom any number, tag or mark indicating
ownership or identity thereof. (Prior Code, Chapter 14, as amended)
 
Notes
1 2. 21 OS 1971, § 1787.
10-203: DESTROYING OR INJURING BUILDINGS AND OTHER PROPERTY 1
:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person to purposely destroy, injure, deface,
besmear, or molest any structure, building, outbuilding, fence, or any other
property, real or personal, public or private, belonging to another or to use
any such property wrongfully to the detriment of the owner or other person
entitled to its use. It is unlawful to interfere wrongfully with the use of any
such property by its owner or any other person entitled to its use.
   B.   It is unlawful for any person to loosen or remove any plank, board,
block, brick, stone, stringer, support or other part from, or to injure or
destroy, any sidewalk, crossing, bridge, culvert, viaduct, gate, sign or other
property of another, without lawful authority. (Prior Code, Chapter 14, as
amended)
 
Notes
1 1. 21 OS § 1760 et seq.
10-204: PLACING SIGNS ON PROPERTY OF ANOTHER:
It is unlawful for any person to place, stick, tack, paste, post, paint, mark,
write or print any sign, poster, picture, announcement, advertisement, bill
placard, device or inscription upon any public or private building, fence,
sidewalk, bridge, viaduct, post, automobile, other vehicle or other property of
another, without the consent of the owner or person in charge thereof. (Prior
Code, Chapter 14, as amended)
10-205: TAMPERING WITH OR DAMAGING PUBLIC UTILITIES, LARCENY:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person to adjust, connect, disconnect, molest,
injure, destroy or in any way tamper with any water or gas pipe, any telephone
pole or apparatus, meterloop, riser or connection belonging thereto, or any
water, gas or electric meter or meter box or housing, or any pipe, wire,
conduit or connection belonging thereto, or any other part of water, gas or
electrical system, or to do any act or use any contrivance to prevent or affect
correct and proper registration by any such meter. This shall not apply to
officers and employees of the city or of any person, firm or corporation owning
or operating such water, gas or electric system, acting in line of duty.
   B.   No person shall, without lawful authority, make any splice, tap or
other connection into or on any cable, wire, pipe or other connection into or
on any cable, wire, pipe or other service furnished to the residents of the
city by the city or by any person, firm or corporation operating in the city
under a valid permit issued by the city.
   C.   Any person who with intent to defraud, makes or causes to be made any
pipe, wire, or other instrument or contrivance and connects the same or causes
the same to be connected with any pipe provided for the purpose of conducting
water or gas, or with any wire or other electrical conductor provided for the
purpose of conducting electricity, so as to conduct such gas, water or electric
current, to a point where the same may be consumed, without its passing through
meters provided for registering the quantity consumed, or in any manner so as
to evade payment therefor, whether the gas, water or electrical current is
furnished through a meter or not, shall be guilty of an offense. Every person
who, with like intent, injures or alters any gas, electric or water meter or
obstructs its action, is guilty of an offense. (Prior Code, Chapter 14, as
amended)
10-206: UNLAWFUL INTRUSION UPON LAND:
It is unlawful for any person to intrude or squat upon any lot or piece of land
within the city without a license or authority from the owner thereof, or to
erect or occupy thereon any hut, hovel, shanty or other structure without such
license or authority, or to place, erect or occupy within the bounds of any
street, alley or avenue of the city, any hut, shanty, hovel, or other structure
without authority of law or ordinance. (Prior Code, Chapter 14, as amended)
10-207: ILLEGAL ENTRANCE:
It is illegal for any person to enter upon the property of another or into an
area or structure on such property (whether such property, area or structure is
public or private), when such entrance is plainly forbidden by signs or
otherwise or when the property, area or structure is enclosed, except when such
entrance is in line of duty, or with the expressed, or tacit consent of the
owner or person in charge, or otherwise by authority of law or ordinance.
(Prior Code, Chapter 14, as amended)
10-208: THROWING ADVERTISING ON STREET PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person to throw, leave or deposit, or cause to be
thrown, left or deposited, upon any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public
area, any handbill, circular, or other advertising matter. (Prior Code, Chapter
14, as amended)
10-209: THROWING INJURIOUS SUBSTANCES:
It is unlawful for any person to purposely or premeditatedly put or throw upon
the person or property of another, or upon any animal, any acid, corrosive or
other irritating or harmful substance, or human or animal waste or urine, with
intent to injure or harass the person, property or animal. (Prior Code, Chapter
14, as amended)
10-210: INJURY TO PUBLIC PLANTS AND TREES:
It is unlawful for any person to wilfully and without authority cut, pull,
pluck or otherwise injure any flowers, flowering plants, shrubs or trees
growing in or around any park or public street within the city, or wilfully or
without authority to tear down, remove, cut or otherwise injure or destroy any
gate or fence enclosing any such park or ground, or wilfully injure or destroy
any stand, bench, seat or other property situated upon such park or ground.
(Prior Code, Chapter 14, as amended)
10-211: PUBLIC STREETS AND TREES:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person to:
      1.   Wilfully or wantonly cut, deface or in any way injure any tree or
sapling standing or growing in any of the streets, alleys or public places
within the city;
      2.   Attach any guy wires, telephone, telegraph, or electric wire, or any
wire to any live tree;
      3.   Dig any hole, ditch or trench in any public street, road, avenue or
alley, or any other public premises or grounds within, belonging to or under
the supervision or control of the city;
      4.   Take or remove any dirt, earth or any substance from any street,
road, alley or other public place in the city; or to cut, break or otherwise
injure any pavement, curb or gutter therein; or
      5.   Connect any driveway to any street or other public place without
first securing permission from the city inspector so to do.
Any such digging, removing, or driveway connection shall be done under the
supervision of the city. (Prior Code, Chapter 14, as amended)
10-212: DAMAGING, DESTROYING TREES, PLANTS OR FRUIT, TRESPASS:
It is unlawful for any person to wilfully cut down, root up, sever, injure or
destroy any fruit tree, shade or ornamental tree, cultivated root, plant, vine,
shrub or bush whatever, which is the property of another, standing on or
attached to the land of another, or to pick, destroy or carry away therefrom or
in any way interfere with any part of the fruit thereof, or to trespass on the
premises of another, without the consent of the owner or person in charge.
(Prior Code, Chapter 14, as amended)
10-213: ALTERING, OBSTRUCTING GUTTERS, DRAINS, STREAMS AND OTHER WATER
PASSAGES:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person to change, alter, deflect, destroy or
injure any gutter, waterway, water outlet, drain, ditch, stream or other water
passage, either natural or artificial, in or upon the streets, avenues, alleys
or other public ways or public property within the city or to change the course
or flow of any water passage or stream running upon his property or upon the
side of the street adjacent to his property in such a manner as to cast the
stream or flow of water into the public street or other public way or upon the
property of another.
   B.   It is unlawful for any person to fill up, deflect or obstruct any
gutter, waterway, water outlet, drain, stream, ditch, sewer or other water
passage, either natural or artificial, by throwing or causing to be thrown
therein any trash, rubbish, garbage, brush or other thing.
   C.   If it becomes necessary to change, alter or in any way interfere with
any gutter, drain, ditch, stream or other water passage, for the purpose of
protecting the streets or other public ways or property, or for the protection
or preservation of the property of any person, it shall be necessary first to
obtain the consent of the city administrator. (Prior Code, Chapter 14, as
amended)
10-214: TRESPASS PROHIBITED:
   A.   For the purpose of this section, the following terms shall be defined
as follows:
    PRIVATE PROPERTY: Any property other than public property.
   PUBLIC PROPERTY: That property which is dedicated to public use and over
which the federal, state or municipal government or any subdivision thereof
exercises control.
   TRESPASS: Each and every actual entry upon the premises of an owner or other
person in lawful possession of the premises without the express or the implied
consent of the owner or other person in lawful possession. Trespass shall also
mean remaining upon the premises of an owner or other person in lawful
possession after having been told to leave the premises by the owner, or the
agent, or employee of the owner, or other person in lawful possession of the
premises. Trespass shall also be defined as the act of remaining on private
property at any time other than during posted hours of business operation after
having been directed to vacate such premises by a police officer; provided that
the provisions of this sentence shall not apply to persons, including
employees, whose presence upon such premises is authorized by the owner or by a
person in lawful possession of such premises; nor shall the provisions of this
sentence apply unless hours of business operations are posted upon such
premises. Trespass shall also be defined as the act of returning to private
property before the posted time of opening for business operation on the next
business day after having been directed to vacate such premises under the terms
of this subsection.
   B.   It is unlawful for any person to trespass on private property. (Prior
Code, Chapter 14, as amended)
10-215: PARKING ON PROPERTY OF ANOTHER PERSON OR BUSINESS:
It is unlawful for any person to park an automobile or other vehicle, or to
place any structure or object on the driveway, parking area, yard, or any
portion of the premises or property of another person or business, including,
but not limited to, any restaurant, gasoline/filling station or other business,
when the business is not open to the public for business without the expressed
or tacit consent of the owner or person in charge thereof, or when necessary in
the performance of a duty, or otherwise by authority of law or ordinance.
(Prior Code, Chapter 14, as amended)
10-216: IMPROPER USE OF DRIVEWAYS AND PARKING AREAS:
It is unlawful for any person to drive a motor vehicle onto the premises,
driveway, or parking area of any place of business without purchasing or
attempting to purchase or obtain service or merchandise thereat. It shall be
considered a violation of this section to drive onto the premises without
stopping and requesting services or attempting to purchase merchandise;
provided nothing herein shall prohibit deliveries of material or merchandise to
the premises. (Prior Code, Chapter 14, as amended)
