ARTICLE A. GENERAL PROVISIONS
17-301: SEWER SYSTEM AS PUBLIC UTILITY:
The operation of the city's sanitary sewer system is hereby declared to be a
public utility and a proper source of city revenues and expenditures for the
upkeep and maintenance of the sewer system. (Prior Code, Sec. 18-17)
17-302: SEWER RATES:
The city council shall from time to time by ordinance or resolution set or
amend the fees and charges for sewer use by customers of the city's sewer
system. A copy of the current fees or charges shall be kept on file in the city
clerk's office. (Prior Code, Sec. 18-36)
17-303: PRIVIES:
Except as hereinafter provided, it is unlawful to construct or maintain any
privy, vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the
disposal of sewage. (Prior Code, Sec. 18-21)
17-304: OPERATION OF PRIVATE SEWER:
The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal facilities in
a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the city. (Prior Code, Sec.
18-25)
17-305: ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS BY HEALTH OFFICER:
No statement contained in this chapter shall be construed to interfere with any
additional requirements that may be imposed by the health officer. (Prior Code,
Sec. 18-26)
17-306: COSTS TO OWNER:
All costs and expense incident to the installation and connection of the
building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city
from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the
installation of the building sewer. (Prior Code, Sec. 18-27)
17-307: EXCAVATIONS:
All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded
with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets,
sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the
work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city council. (Prior
Code, Sec. 18-28)
17-308: MATERIAL 1
:
All house sewers shall be constructed in accordance with specifications
contained within the current city plumbing code. (Prior Code, Sec. 18-29, as
amended)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  5-201 of this code.
17-309: INTERCEPTORS:
   A.   Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the
opinion of the city council, they are necessary for the proper handling of
liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes,
sand, and other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be
required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall
be of a type and capacity approved by the city board and shall be located as to
be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection.
   B.   Grease and oil interceptors shall be constructed of impervious
materials capable of withstanding abrupt and extreme changes in temperature.
They shall be of substantial construction, watertight, and equipped with easily
removable covers which when bolted in place shall be gastight and watertight.
(Prior Code, Sec. 18-33)
17-310: DAMAGE TO SEWAGE SYSTEM:
No unauthorized person shall maliciously, wilfully, or negligently break,
damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, or
equipment which is a part of the municipal sewage works. Any person violating
this provision shall be subject to immediate arrest under charge of disorderly
conduct. (Prior Code, Sec. 18-34)
17-311: POWERS AND AUTHORITY OF INSPECTORS:
The city board and duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper
credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter upon all properties
for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, and
testing, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (Prior Code, Sec.
18-35)
ARTICLE B.  SEWER USE REGULATIONS
17-320: DEFINITIONS:
Definitions used herein:
ACT OR THE ACT: The federal water pollution control act, also known as the
clean water act, as amended, 33 USC 1251 et seq.
APPROVAL AUTHORITY: The commissioner of the Oklahoma state department of health
or the administrator of the U.S. environmental protection agency, region VI.
BIOCHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND (BOD): The quantity of oxygen used in the biochemical
oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure, five (5) days
at twenty degrees centigrade (20°C), expressed in terms of weight and
concentration in milligrams per liter (mg/l).
BUILDING SEWER: The extension from the building drain to the sewer or other
place of disposal.
CHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND (COD): A measure of the oxygen consuming capacity
expressed in mg/l, of organic and inorganic matter present in water or
wastewater. It is expressed as the amount of oxygen consumed from a chemical
oxidant in a specific test. It does not differentiate between stable and
unstable matter and thus does not necessarily correlate with biochemical oxygen
demand.
CITY: The city of Harrah, Oklahoma, or any authorized person acting on its
behalf.
COOLING WATER: The water discharged from any use such as air conditioning,
cooling or refrigeration or to which the only pollutant added is heat.
DOMESTIC WASTEWATER: Waterborne wastewater normally discharging into the
sanitary conveniences of dwellings (including apartment houses and hotels),
office buildings, factories and institutions and commercial establishments.
ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY OR EPA: The U.S. environmental protection
agency, or where appropriate, the term may also be used as a designation for
the administrator or other duly authorized official of the agency.
GARBAGE: The animal and vegetable wastes and residue from the preparation,
cooking, and dispensing of food; and from the handling, processing, storage,
and sale of food products and produce.
INDUSTRIAL WASTE: Waterborne solids, liquids or gaseous wastes resulting from
and discharged, permitted to flow, or escaping from the industrial
manufacturing or food processing operation or process, or from the development
of any natural resource or any mixture of these with water or domestic
wastewater, or distinct from normal domestic wastewater.
MILLIGRAMS PER LITER (mg/l): The same as parts per million and is a weight-to-
weight volume ratio. The mg/l value multiplied by the factor eight and thirty
four hundredths (8.34) is equivalent to pounds per million gallons of water.
NATURAL WATERCOURSE: Any outlet into a watercourse, ditch, lake or other body
of surface or ground water.
NORMAL DOMESTIC WASTEWATER: Normal wastewater for the city in which the average
concentration of suspended solids and five (5) day BOD is established at not
more than two hundred fifty milligrams per liter (250 mg/l).
PERSON: Any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, corporation,
association, joint stock company, trust, estate, governmental entity or other
legal entity, or their legal representatives, agents or assigns. The masculine
gender shall include the feminine, the singular shall include the plural where
indicated by the context.
pH: The logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the concentration of hydrogen
ions expressed in grams per liter of solution.
POLLUTANT: Any dredged spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, sewage,
garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, chemical wastes, biological materials,
radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discharged equipment, rock, sand,
cellar dirt and industrial, municipal, or agricultural waste discharged into
water.
POLLUTION: Manmade or man-induced alteration of the physical, chemical,
biological or radiological integrity of water.
PROPERLY SHREDDED GARBAGE: Wastes from the preparation, cooking, and dispensing
of food, that have been shredded to such degree that all particles are carried
freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no
particles greater than one-half inch (1/2") in any dimension.
PUBLIC SEWER: A sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal
rights and the use of which is controlled by public authority.
SANITARY SEWER: A sewer that conveys domestic or industrial wastes or a
combination of both and into which storm, surface and ground water or
unpolluted wastes are not intentionally passed.
SEWER: A pipe or conduit that carries wastewater or drainage water.
STANDARD ANALYSIS METHODS: The examination and analytical procedures set forth
in the latest edition, at the time of analysis, of "Methods for Chemical
Analysis of Water and Wastes", prepared by the EPA, water quality control
laboratory, Cincinnati, Ohio.
STORM WATER: Any flow occurring during or following any form of natural
precipitation and resulting therefrom.
SUPERINTENDENT: The person designated by the city to supervise the operation of
the publicly owned treatment works and who is charged with certain duties and
responsibilities by this article, or his duly authorized representative.
SUSPENDED SOLIDS: The total suspended matter that floats on the surface of, or
is suspended in, water, wastewater or other liquids, and which is removed by
laboratory filtering.
TOXIC POLLUTANT: Any pollutant or combination of pollutants listed as toxic in
regulations promulgated by the administrator of the environmental protection
agency under the provision of CWA 307(a) and other acts.
WASTEWATER: The liquid and water carrying industrial or domestic wastes from
dwellings, commercial buildings, industrial facilities, and institutions,
together with any ground water, surface water, and storm water that may be
present, whether treated or untreated, which is contributed into or permitted
to enter the wastewater facilities.
WASTEWATER FACILITIES: All facilities of the city used for collection, pumping,
treating, and disposing of wastewater and industrial wastes.
WATERS OF THE STATE: All streams, lakes, ponds, marshes, watercourses,
waterways, wells, springs, reservoirs, aquifers, irrigation systems, drainage
systems and all other bodies or accumulations of water, surface or underground,
natural or artificial, public or private, which are contained within, flow
through or border upon the state or any portion thereof. (Ord. 1986-6, 6-5-
1986)
17-321: PROHIBITED DISCHARGES:
   A.   No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the
following described waters or wastes to the wastewater facilities. Toxic
materials and metals shall not be diluted and discharged to the system in lieu
of treatment:
      1. Any gasoline, benzene, naptha, fuel oil or other flammable or
explosive liquid, solid or gas.
      2. Any storm water, surface water, ground water, roof runoff, subsurface
drainage or uncontaminated cooling water to any sanitary sewer. Storm water and
all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are
specifically designed as storm sewers or to a natural watercourse approved by
the city.
      3. Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred fifty
degrees Fahrenheit (150°F) or any discharge which causes the temperature of the
total wastewater treatment plant influent to increase at a rate of ten degrees
Fahrenheit (10°F) or more per hour or a combined total increase to a plant
influent temperature of one hundred four degrees Fahrenheit (104°F).
      4. Any water or waste containing fats, wax, grease, or oils, whether
emulsified or not, in excess of one hundred milligrams per liter (100 mg/l) or
containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures
between thirty two degrees (32°) and one hundred four degrees Fahrenheit
(104°F).
      5. Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation and
operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths (3/4)
horsepower (0.76 hp metric) or greater shall be subject to the review and
approval of the city.
      6. Any waters or wastes containing strong acid, iron pickling wastes or
concentrated plating solutions whether neutralized or not.
      7. Any waters or wastes containing objectionable, toxic, or poisonous
substances, or wastes exerting an excessive chlorine requirement.
      8. Any waters or wastes containing obnoxious, toxic, or poisonous solids,
liquids or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with
other wastes to injure or interfere with any wastewater treatment process,
constitute a hazard to humans or animals or create any hazard in the receiving
waters of the wastewater treatment plant.
      9. Any waters or wastes having pH lower than five (5.0) or higher than
nine and five-tenths (9.5), having any other corrosive property capable of
causing damage or hazard to structure, equipment and personnel at the
wastewater facilities.
      10. Solids or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable of
causing obstruction to the flow in sewers or other interference with the proper
operation of the wastewater works, such as, but not limited to, ashes, cinders,
sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood,
unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair, fleshings, entrails, and
paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either whole or ground by garbage
grinders, lime slurry, lime residues, slops, chemical residues, paint residues
or bulk solids.
      11. Any waters or wastes containing phenols, hydrogen sulfide or other
taste and odor producing substances.
      12. Any radioactive wastes or isotopes.
      13. Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to
treatment processes employed by the city or are amenable to treatment only to
such degree that the wastewater treatment plant effluent cannot meet the
requirements of other agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the
receiving stream.
      14. The discharge of any pollutant listed below into the city sewer
system is prohibited, except in amounts that do not exceed the concentration
limits established by a city permit to discharge for a specific industrial
user. The prohibited materials are:
         a. Antimony.
         b. Arsenic.
         c. Barium.
         d. Beryllium.
         e. Bismuth ion.
         f. Boron.
         g. Cadmium.
         h. Chromium (hexavalent).
         i. Chromium (trivalent).
         j. Cobalt.
         k. Copper.
         l. Iron.
         m. Lead.
         n. Manganese.
         o. Mercury.
         p. Molybdenum.
         q. Nickel.
         r. Rhenium.
         s. Selenium.
         t. Silver.
         u. Strontium.
         v. Tellurium.
         w. Tin.
         x. Uranyl ion.
         y. Zinc.
   B.   No person may discharge to the public sewers any waste which by itself
or by interaction with other wastes may:
      1. Injure or interfere with the wastewater treatment processes or
facilities of the city.
      2. Constitute a hazard to humans or animals.
      3. Create a hazard in receiving waters for the wastewater treatment
facilities.
   C.   No persons shall deposit or discharge any wastewater or other polluted
liquids on public or private property in or adjacent to any natural
watercourse, or in any storm sewer or in any area under the jurisdiction of the
city, without the approval of the city. (Ord. 1986-6, 6-5-1986)
17-322: INDUSTRIAL USERS:
It is the intention of the city to regulate present and future industrial
wastewater which might be discharged by a user of the facilities. Wastewater
introduced into the facilities shall contain no toxics or other pollutants in
amount or concentration that endangers public safety or the physical integrity
of the treatment works; or causes violation of the water quality standards; or
precludes the use of the most cost effective treatment method. (Ord. 1986-6, 6-
5-1986)
17-323: NEW CONNECTIONS FROM INFLOW SOURCES PROHIBITED:
Any new connections from inflow sources into the sanitary sewer system are
prohibited. (Ord. 1986-6, 6-5-1986)
17-324: USER TREATMENT:
   A.   Users shall provide necessary wastewater treatment as required to
comply with this article and shall achieve compliance with all federal
categorical pretreatment standards within the time limitations as specified by
the federal pretreatment regulations. Any facilities required to pretreat
wastewater to a level acceptable to the city are provided, operated, and
maintained at the users' expense. Detailed plans showing the pretreatment
facilities and operating procedures are submitted to the city for review, and
are acceptable to the city before construction of the facility. The review of
such plans and operating procedures will in no way relieve the user from the
responsibility of modifying the facility as necessary to produce an effluent
acceptable to the city under the provisions of this article. Any subsequent
changes in the pretreatment facilities or method of operation shall be reported
to and be acceptable to the city prior to the users' initiation of the change.
   B.   All records relating to compliance with these requirements are made
available to officials of the EPA and the approval authority (Oklahoma state
department of health) on request. (Ord. 1986-6, 6-5-1986)
17-325: TESTING:
All wastewater testing requirements for compliance with this article are
accomplished in accordance with standard analysis methods. (Ord. 1986-6, 6-5-
1986)
17-326: USE OF SYSTEM REQUIRED:
   A.   The public sewer system and wastewater facilities will be used wherever
such system is available by all persons discharging any wastewater or other
polluted liquids which are not otherwise prohibited, unless an exception is
granted by the city.
   B.   The city in providing approval will verify that such wastes will
receive treatment within the provisions of federal, state or local laws,
regulations or ordinances, before discharge. (Ord. 1986-6, 6-5-1986)
17-327: CONNECTIONS:
   A.   The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall
conform to the requirements of the city approved plumbing code and other
applicable rules and regulations of the city and the approval authority.
   B.   All new hookups of a building sewer line to a public sewer line or a
private line approved for multiple users shall be equipped at each point of
entry to a structure with a backflow prevention valve. Installation of said
valve shall be the responsibility of the property owner; and no certificate of
occupancy shall be issued until the necessary valves have been installed,
inspected, and approved by the city. The valve shall be located between the
clean out opening and the sewer main and be set below the frost line. (Ord.
2004-4, 3-18-2004)
17-328: SEWAGE WORKS:
All new sanitary sewage works are designed and constructed in accordance with
regulations promulgated by the city and the approval authority. (Ord. 1986-6,
6-5-1986)
17-329: CONNECTION TO PUBLIC SEWER REQUIRED, WITH EXCEPTION:
   A.   Subject to the exception in subsection B of this section, all
residences, including, but not limited to, single- and multi- family housing
units, dwelling houses and all buildings or property used for business or
commercial establishment of any type, situated within the city, and abutting on
any street, alley or right of way within three hundred feet (300') of which
there is now located, or may in the future be located, a public sanitary sewer
of the city, are hereby required, at their expense, to install suitable toilet
facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the
provisions of this code.
   B.   As an exception to subsection A of this section, all users with working
systems as of August 17, 1995, may apply to the city for payment of an
inspection fee at no cost in lieu of hookup to the public sanitary sewer;
provided, however, that the application must be accompanied by an inspection
report issued by the state health department or the city-county health
department or other inspection acceptable to the city, stating that the agency
has inspected the applicant's septic system and found that the same is
functioning properly and constitutes no present health hazard. The application
shall be submitted to the planning commission for review at the next regularly
scheduled meeting and then to the city council for final action. Any exceptions
granted under subsection A of this section shall be subject to periodic review
and may be canceled if the system is no longer functioning properly or
constitutes a present health hazard. In this event users must comply with
subsection A of this section. (Ord. 1986-6, 6-5-1986; amd. Ord. 1995-9, 8-17-
1995)
17-330: APPLICATION:
Any person desiring to connect the city sewer system shall make a written
application to the city clerk for a permit. Before any such permit is issued,
such applicant must request that the clerk or superintendent inspect and
supervise any and all connections with the sewer system. The applicant shall
pay in advance the sum as set by the city council. After the request for
inspection has been filed, and the fee paid, the clerk shall issue a permit to
such applicant; under no circumstances shall any connection be made to the
sewer system except under the supervision of the city clerk or the
superintendent. The permit shall contain a description of the lot or tract of
property to be served by the sewer system. (Ord. 1986-6, 6-5-1986)
17-331: OWNER OBLIGATION:
The permit required in section 17-330 of this article shall contain an
obligation for the property owner or the person procuring the same to construct
and supply the physical material to connect to the existing sewer system of the
original plat, in accordance with the plan, plat, and specification adopted and
in force within the city. (Ord. 1986-6, 6-5-1986)
17-332: FEES:
All fees for services outlined under this article shall be payable to the
official designated by the city council and the water collector, city
treasurer, and city clerk shall assist therein. (Ord. 1986-6, 5-5-1986)
17-333: INFILTRATION ALLOWANCES:
The allowable infiltration for all sewers is hereby established at no more than
two hundred (200) gallons per inch of sewer diameter per mile per day for
sewers twenty four inches (24") in diameter and smaller. All new sewers shall
be tested for infiltration in accordance with an acceptable testing method.
(Ord. 1986-6, 6-5-1986)
17-334: POWERS AND AUTHORITY OF INSPECTORS:
   A.   The superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the city
bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all
properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling,
and testing in accordance with the provisions of this article. The
superintendent or his representatives shall have no authority to inquire into
any processes including metallurgical, chemical, oil refining, ceramic, paper,
or other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and
source of discharge to the sewers, waterways, or facilities for waste
treatment.
   B.   While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to
in subsection A of this section, the superintendent or duly authorized
employees of the city shall observe all safety rules applicable to the
premises, established by the company, and the company shall be held harmless
for injury or death of the city employees, and the city shall indemnify the
company against loss or damage to its property by city employees and against
damage asserted against the company and growing out of the gauging or sampling
operation, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the company
to maintain safe conditions as required.
   C.   The superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the city
bearing proper credentials and identification are permitted to enter all
private properties through which the city holds duly negotiated easements for
the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement,
sampling, repair, and maintenance of any portion of the sewerage system lying
within the easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on the easement,
shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement
pertaining to the private property involved. (Ord. 1986-6, 6-5-1986)
17-335: PENALTIES:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person to maliciously, wilfully or negligently
break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure,
appurtenance, or equipment which is a part of the sewage works. Any person
violating this provision is subject to immediate arrest under charge of
disorderly conduct.
   B.   Any person found to be violating any provision of this article is
served by the city with written notice stating the nature of the violation and
providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. The
offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently
cease all violations.
   C.   Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall become
liable to the city for any expense, loss or damage occasioned the city by
reason of such violation.
   D.   Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit
provided for in this section is deemed guilty of a violation thereof and upon
conviction thereof is punishable as provided in section
1-108 of this code. Each day in which any such violation shall continue is
deemed a separate offense. (Ord. 1986-6, 6-5-1986)
ARTICLE C.  USER CHARGE REGULATIONS
17-340: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise the following terms and
phrases, as used in this article, shall have the meanings hereinafter
designated:
BIOCHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND (BOD): The quantity of oxygen used in the biochemical
oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure, five (5) days
at twenty degrees centigrade (20°C), expressed in terms of weight and
concentration in milligrams per liter (mg/l).
DOMESTIC WASTEWATER: The waterborne wastewater normally discharging into the
sanitary conveniences of dwellings (including apartment houses and hotels),
office buildings, factories and institutions and commercial establishments.
INFILTRATION: The water entering a sewer system, including sewer service
connections, from the ground, through such means, but not limited to, defective
pipes, pipe joints, connections, or manhole walls. Infiltration does not
include, and is distinguished from, inflow.
INFLOW: The water discharged into a sewer system, including sewer connections,
from such sources as roof leaders, cellar, yard and area drains, foundation
drains, cooling water discharges, drains from springs and swampy areas, manhole
covers, cross-connections from storm sewers or combined sewers, catch basins,
storm waters, surface runoff, street wash waters or drainage.
NORMAL DOMESTIC WASTEWATER: Normal wastewater for the city in which the average
concentration of suspended solids and five (5) day BOD is established at not
more than two hundred fifty milligrams per liter (250 mg/l), for each
constituent.
OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE: The activities that are required to assure the
dependable and economical function of the wastewater collection and treatment
facilities. Operation is the control of the component unit processes, equipment
and facilities including financial and personnel management records, laboratory
control, process control, safety and emergency operation planning. Maintenance
is the preservation of the functional integrity and efficiency of the
equipment, structures and facilities including preventive maintenance,
corrective maintenance and replacement of equipment as needed.
POLLUTANT: Any dredged spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, sewage,
garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, chemical wastes, biological materials,
radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discharged equipment, rock, sand,
cellar dirt and industrial, municipal, and agricultural waste discharged into
water.
STORM WATER: Any flow occurring during or following any form of natural
precipitation and resulting therefrom.
SUSPENDED SOLIDS: The total suspended matter that floats on the surface of, or
is suspended in, water, wastewater or other liquids, and which is removable by
laboratory filtering.
TOXIC POLLUTANT: Any pollutant or combination of pollutants listed as toxic in
regulations promulgated by the administrator of the U.S. environmental
protection agency under the provision of section 307(a) of the "Clean Water
Act", as amended, or any other acts.
USER: Any person who contributes, causes or permits the contribution of
wastewater into the city's wastewater collection system.
USER CHARGE: Those charges levied on users of the wastewater facilities for the
costs of operation and maintenance of such facilities.
WASTEWATER: The liquid and water-carried industrial or domestic wastes from
dwellings, commercial buildings, industrial facilities, and institutions,
together with any ground water, surface water, and storm water that may be
present, whether treated or untreated, which is contributed into or permitted
to enter the city's wastewater collection system. (Ord. 1986-7, 6-5-1986)
17-341: SEWER USER CHARGES:
   A.   All users of the municipally owned wastewater treatment system shall be
charged a minimum determined by the city council based on the first two
thousand (2,000) gallons of metered water consumption plus a council approved
charge for each additional one thousand (1,000) gallons of metered water
consumption above the minimum per month. (A current fee schedule shall be on
file in the city clerk's office.) (Ord. 2001-03, 2-1-2001)
   B.    In the case of users not on a metered basis, the city shall establish
an estimated water consumption based on a comparison of the nonmetered user
with a metered user of similar type. Example: A nonmetered family of four (4)
will be compared to a typical family of four (4) with a water meter to
establish water consumption.
   C.   As the BOD5, suspended solids, and other pollutant concentrations
discharged are approximately equal for all domestic type users, users shall be
charged on a volume basis in accordance with the following formula which is
based on title 40, part 35.935-13, "Federal Water Pollution Control Act", 1972,
as amended, appendix B, model #1.
   Cu = Cb + Ct/Vt (Vu)
Symbols And Definitions:
Cu   =    A users charge for operation and maintenance (O&M) per unit of time;
Cb   =    A users base minimum charge (for debt retirement, billing,
administration, etc.) per unit of time;
Ct   =    Total O&M costs per unit of time;
Vt   =    Total volume from all users per unit of time. May include extraneous
flows;
Vu   =    Volume from a user per unit of time.
   D.   The user charge system and requirements of this article shall take
precedence over any items or conditions of agreements or contracts between the
city and any of the users which are inconsistent with applicable federal
regulations regarding user charge systems. (Ord. 1986-7, 6-5-1986)
17-342: EXCESSIVE STRENGTH CHARGES:
For any user, when the BOD5 exceeds the maximum limit for average domestic
waste two hundred fifty milligrams per liter (250 mg/l), the suspended solids
exceeds the maximum limit for average domestic waste two hundred fifty
milligrams per liter (250 mg/l), or when other pollutant concentrations exceed
the range of concentrations of these pollutants in normal domestic sewage, a
surcharge shall be added to the basic charge as determined under this article.
This surcharge shall be calculated by the following formula which is based on
title 40, part 35.935-13, "Federal Water Pollution Control Act", 1972, as
amended, appendix B, model #2.
   Cs = [Bc(B)+Sc(S)+Pc(P)]Vu
Symbols And Definitions:
Cs   =    A surcharge for wastewater of excessive strength.
Bc   =    O&M cost for treatment of a unit of biochemical oxygen demand (BOD).
B    =    Concentration of BOD from a user above a base level.
Sc   =    O&M cost for treatment of a unit of suspended solids (TSS).
S    =    Concentration of suspended solids from a user above a base level.
Pc   =    O&M cost for treatment of a unit of any pollutant;
P    =    Concentration of any pollutant from a user above a base level.
Vu   =    Volume from a user per unit of time.
(Ord. 1986-7, 6-5-1986)
17-343: TOXIC POLLUTANT CHARGE:
Each user that discharges any toxic pollutants which cause an increase in the
cost of managing the facilities used as the wastewater treatment works shall
pay for such increased costs. (Ord. 1986-7, 6-5-1986)
17-344: EXTRANEOUS FLOWS CHARGE:
The costs of operation and maintenance for all flows not directly attributable
to users (such as infiltration/inflow) shall be distributed among users on the
same basis as operation and maintenance charges. (Ord. 1986-7, 6-5-1986)
17-345: NOTIFICATION:
Each user shall be notified at least annually, in conjunction with the regular
bill, of the sewer rate and the portion of the user charge which is
attributable to wastewater treatment services. Costs shall be broken down to
show the operation and maintenance costs attributable to that user. (Ord. 1986-
7, 6-5-1986)
17-346: REVIEW AND REVISION:
   A.   The user charge system and ordinance shall be reviewed not less often
than every two (2) years regarding the wastewater contribution of users and
user classes, the total costs of the operation and maintenance of the treatment
works, and its approved user charge system. The charges for users or user
classes shall be revised to accomplish the following:
      1.   Maintain the proportionate distribution of operation and maintenance
costs among users and user classes.
      2.   Generate sufficient revenue to pay the total operation and
maintenance costs necessary to the proper operation and maintenance (including
replacement) of the treatment works.
      3.   Apply excess revenue collected from a class of users to the costs of
operation and maintenance attributable to that class for the next year, and the
rates shall be adjusted accordingly. (Ord. 1986-7, 6-5-1986)
17-347: RECORDS:
A record keeping system is established and maintained by the city to document
compliance with federal regulations pertaining to the user charge regulations.
(Ord. 1986-7, 6-5-1996)
17-348: BILLING:
   A.   Users will be billed on a monthly basis with payment due on the due
date. Users of the wastewater system will be billed on the same notice as water
charges and will be designated as a separate entry. Users of the wastewater
system not on water service will be billed monthly on an individual notice for
wastewater service at the rate established by the city.
   B.   Users with delinquent accounts will be notified in writing by the city
that water or wastewater services will be terminated unless the account is paid
in full. The city will utilize the law enforcement agency to assist as required
in the control and management of the user charge system.
   C.   In all cases where more than one user utilizes the same meter, in
addition to the rates provided for in this article, four dollars ($4.00) per
user shall be charged. (Ord. 1986-7, 6-5-1986)
   D.   A late payment penalty computed at a percentage rate established and
approved by the Harrah city council on the monthly unpaid balance will be
payable on all sewer bills not paid on the fifteenth day of the month for which
payment is due. (The current late payment percentage amount shall be kept on
the fee schedule filed in the city clerk's office.) (Ord. 2001-03, 2-1-2001)
CHAPTER 4
GARBAGE AND REFUSE COLLECTION
SECTION:
17-401: Definitions
17-402: Collection Of Garbage And Other Refuse
17-403: Unlawful Removal From Container
17-404: Not To Be Nuisance, Containers
17-405: Duty Of Occupant And Owner To Request Services
17-406: Noncollectible Waste
17-407: Private Removal
17-408: Container Required; Duty To Use
17-409: Violations; Penalty
17-401: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases when used in this code shall have the
meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
BUSINESS, COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENT OR INSTITUTION: Includes any building or
structure or premises not defined as a residence.
COLLECTIBLE SOLID WASTE: All solid waste including, but not limited to, garbage
or trash except noncollectible or hazardous waste.
GARBAGE: All putrescible waste from any place where meats, fish, fowls, fruits,
or vegetables are prepared for food for consumption and shall include all
household waste including organic matter that has been prepared for or was
intended to be used as food or has resulted from the preparation of food.
HAZARDOUS WASTE: Materials or substances which by reason of their compensation
or characteristics are: a) hazardous waste as defined in the solid waste
disposable act, 42 USC section 691 et seq., or the regulations thereunder, or
the Oklahoma hazardous waste disposable act, 63 Oklahoma Statutes section
1-2001 et seq., or the regulations thereunder, in any similar or substituted
legislation or regulation or amendments to the foregoing; b) any other material
which any governmental agency or unit having appropriate jurisdiction shall
determine from time to time are harmful, toxic or dangerous.
MULTI-FAMILY DWELLING UNITS: Apartments, condominiums, rooming houses, boarding
houses or any other dwelling unit intended for occupancy by more than one
family.
MUNICIPAL SOLID WASTE: Collectible solid waste.
NONCOLLECTIBLE WASTE: Includes pathological and hospital waste, poisons, acids,
caustics, explosives, body wastes, automobile frames, crank cases,
transmissions, large truck tires, large bulky objects such as stoves,
refrigerators, furniture, trees and materials that may cause damage to
collection equipment or personal injury to collectors, dirt, rocks, or debris
resulting from construction, reconstruction or repairs of buildings, animal
excreta, or any article of substance soil by human or animal excreta that has
not been wrapped and tightly sealed in moisture proof paper prior to placement
for collection, and refuse which has been combined or mixed with any of the
above mentioned items, sewage, liquid waste and other highly diluted water
carried materials or substances and those in gaseous form, special nuclear
material or byproducts and materials, as defined in the atomic energy act of
1954, as amended, or hazardous waste.
OCCUPANT OF PREMISES: The occupant of any premises within the city.
OWNER: The owner of all premises where more than one family resides on a lot, a
parcel of land, or adjoining lots or parcels of land belonging to the same
person, unless the premises occupied by each family, including the yards, are
clearly defined and under the exclusive control of the occupant.
PREMISES: Land, buildings, or other structures or parts thereof, or in which
refuse is stored or accumulated.
REFUSE: All putrescible and nonputrescible solid waste including garbage,
rubbish and trash.
RESIDENCE: Any building or structure used solely as a family domicile including
single-family or multi-family dwelling units, duplexes, triplexes, and trailer
courts, but shall not include hotels, tourist courts, motels, motor courts,
motor hotels, or apartment hotels.
RUBBISH: A normal accumulation by resident families or commercial
establishments of worthless or offensive matter, the accumulation of which may
create a nuisance or be deleterious to public health or offensive to sight or
smell.
TRASH: Nonputrescible solid waste, including excessive accumulations of
household rubbish, but shall not include waste matter that is not in a proper
container or is not specified in this chapter.
UNDER ACCUMULATION: The accumulation of garbage, rubbish or trash in amounts
exceeding the capacity of the waste receptacle at the pick up point or at the
point of disposal. (Ord. 2004-8, 8-5-2004)
17-402: COLLECTION OF GARBAGE AND OTHER REFUSE:
   A.   The city may collect and dispose of garbage or other refuse or may
contract with private persons to do so and may contract for collection of all
or some portion of the city.
   B.   It is unlawful for any person or entity not authorized by contract with
the city, or by permit from the city, to collect, transport or dispose of
garbage or other refuse for hire within the city limits. (Ord. 1984-14, 7-19-
1984; amd. Ord. 1991-6, 6-6-1991; Ord. 2004-8, 8-5-2004)
17-403: UNLAWFUL REMOVAL FROM CONTAINER:
It is unlawful for any person without a permit or license issued by the city of
Harrah to remove or cause to be removed any garbage, refuse or rubbish of any
kind from any garbage can or other container used for the deposit of same.
(Ord. 2004-8, 8-5-2004)
17-404: NOT TO BE NUISANCE, CONTAINERS:
All garbage and other refuse on all premises within the city shall be cared for
in a manner which shall prevent it from becoming a nuisance. It is unlawful to
dump trash or other refuse on any property in the city. (Prior Code, Sec. 9-2;
amd. Ord. 2004-8, 8-5-2004)
17-405: DUTY OF OCCUPANT AND OWNER TO REQUEST SERVICES:
   A.   Every person occupying or having control of the occupancy of any
premises located on a regularly established refuse route shall notify the city
of Harrah of the beginning of such occupancy and request refuse pick up
service. Failure of any owner, rental agent or occupant of such premises to
make a request shall not prevent nor in any way impair or impede the city of
Harrah from: 1) adding the address of the premises to the proper refuse
collection route records; 2) providing such service; 3) enforcing by
appropriate action provisions of this chapter and causing the collection fee or
charge to be paid.
   B.   Any place, abode, residence or any other place of business occupied
and/or in operation shall be prima facie evidence that garbage, rubbish, and/or
trash is being produced and accumulated on the premises.
   C.   It is mandatory that every person occupying or having control of the
occupancy of any premises located on a regularly established refuse route
within the city of Harrah use the refuse collection contractors approved by the
city of Harrah for removal of refuse and to pay the rates approved by the city
of Harrah for such service.
   D.   Exceptions to the provisions of this section are as follows:
      1.   If an individual owns or occupies both a business premises and a
residential premises on a regularly established refuse route an election, in
writing, may be given to the city of Harrah to receive service at one location
only and the customer shall be charged only for the selected location. Pick up
of garbage shall occur at only the selected location.
      2.   An owner or occupant of any premises in the city of Harrah may apply
to the city manager for an exception to the requirements contained in this
section. The city manager may grant such an exception upon a showing that the
service is not necessary for the premises for which the owner or occupant is
requesting the exception. Service provided by a private hauler, not approved by
the city of Harrah, shall not be grounds for an exception. Application shall be
made on an as needed basis, with the granting of an exception not to exceed one
year, without a new application for an exception. Vacancy of the premises for a
period in excess of thirty (30) days, with no accumulation of garbage, shall be
grounds for such an exception until the premises is again occupied. (Ord. 2004-
8, 8-5-2004)
17-406: NONCOLLECTIBLE WASTE:
Noncollectible waste shall not be placed with refuse for collection but shall
be disposed of directly and promptly by the person owning, occupying, renting
or leasing the premises wherein such material is accumulated. (Ord. 2004-8, 8-
5-2004)
17-407: PRIVATE REMOVAL:
   A.   No person shall remove from premises situated in the city of Harrah, or
transport through streets, alleys, public places in the city of Harrah, any
garbage, refuse, carcasses of dead animals or other offensive or unwholesome
matter unless authorized by the city of Harrah, except under the provision of
subsection
17-405D1 of this chapter.
   B.   It is unlawful for any person to deposit for collection on any street,
parking lot or on any private property in the city, any garbage, refuse or
rubbish without placing the same in the enclosed containers provided. (Ord.
2004-8, 8-5-2004)
17-408: CONTAINER REQUIRED; DUTY TO USE:
   A.   Except as otherwise provided in this chapter all residential customers
shall place their garbage and refuse in the carts provided by the city or its
designee.
   B.   The city shall provide one cart per residence. The resident shall place
normal household "garbage" and "refuse" as defined in this chapter in the cart
for collection. The resident shall be responsible for the safekeeping of the
cart until such time as an inspection is made by the city and service is
terminated. Should any person change residence, they shall promptly notify the
city. If the cart is lost or stolen the resident shall promptly notify the
police department and obtain a case number. Lost or stolen carts will not be
replaced without a case number from the police department. The city will empty
the cart so long as the cart contains no more than two hundred (200) pounds of
garbage and refuse during any given pick up. If a cart is damaged beyond normal
wear and tear the cost of replacement shall be charged to the resident at the
current replacement cost. All carts shall remain the property of the city even
though the resident has paid for a replacement cart. All carts are to remain at
the residence to which they are assigned. It shall be unlawful and an offense
for a person to be in possession of a cart without the permission of the
resident to which it is assigned.
   C.   All carts to be emptied shall be placed at the city or curb line unless
specific permission to do otherwise has been granted by the city manager due to
special circumstances. Carts are not to be obstructed from view, i.e., behind
parked cars, behind hedges, etc. The carts shall be placed for collection no
earlier than seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. the day before collection and no later
than seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. the day of collection. The resident must return
the cart to its storage place by seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. the day of
collection.
   D.   No other carts or containers for the collection of garbage shall be
utilized by any resident without the written approval of the city of Harrah.
(Ord. 2004-8, 8-5-2004)
17-409: VIOLATIONS; PENALTY:
The owner, occupant, or person having control of any premises in the city of
Harrah who fails to follow any of the provisions of this chapter or who
attempts to remove any refuse, except as provided by this chapter shall be
deemed guilty of an offense. For each twenty four (24) hour period following
conviction, if such person further fails to comply with provisions of this
chapter, he shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense. The fine for such
offense shall be as provided in section
1-108 of this code and in the schedule of fines approved by the city council
and maintained by the city clerk. (Ord. 2004-8, 8-5-2004)
PART 18
FLOOD AND DRAINAGE CONTROL MANAGEMENT

FLOOD DAMAGE PREVENTION ORDINANCE
